reviews.review_pros: I absolutely love working with Nancy my direct supervisor. She is knowledgeable and extremely helpful. When she doesn't know the answer she finds it for you, or gets you in contact with who you need to be in order to get results. She is helpful with advancement and discussing my goals and how we should take which steps in order to get there. Nancy has been the highlight for me with management in this organization and really made me feel welcomed. This has been a wonderful entry level management position to learn and grow.
reviews.review_cons: The best piece of advice I have for potential employees is to really read and make sure you understand the benefits. The PTO/ CLB, the Insurance premiums and copays. It is different under the Hospital and Under the Medical Group .... for some it truly will matter be sure to know what you are signing up for.
reviews.review_advice: Make sure to really recognize staff that go above and beyond.... versus the staff that show up.

reviews.review_pros: convenient, used to be a nice place to work.
reviews.review_cons: Miserable place to work. Poor leadership in the operating room, limited growth for most, promote the inept and praise them while patting themselves on the back.
reviews.review_advice: Learn to lead, learn to manage, get some people skills or move on and let the staff do their job without interference and favoritism.

review_employer_responses.response_text:
We appreciate your feedback and are concerned that you feel a lack of opportunity for growth.    There has been much work in the past few years to assist both leaders and staff in their growth and development.  In the OR, we do have Team Leader and Charge Nurse opportunities and there is a clinical ladder for nurses and surgical technologists as well.

We encourage you to reach out to the Manager, Employee Relations at 443-481-1971 to further discuss your specific concerns.

reviews.review_summary: Find employment with a more reputable  medical institution, one that cares about their employess. They're out there!

reviews.review_pros: Lots of OT offered

reviews.review_pros: You make great friends. That's it....
reviews.review_cons: Everything, management is horrible. They are so concentrated on the Physical Therapists they could give two poops less about anybody else. You get no respect whatsoever. Upper management is corrupt at it's best and have all of the site coordinators brain washed. You do not get respect when needed, instead things get turned onto you in a negative way. This is the worst place to work, if you want somewhere you can grow, this is NOT the place for you. If you want somewhere that will pay you what you are worth, this is NOT the place.  They use you and run you over every change they get, you will be burnt out really fast.
reviews.review_summary: WOULD NOT RECOMMEND WORKING FOR AAMG PT
reviews.review_advice: Care about your employees, pay them what they are worth. LISTEN to their ideas and worries, if they are thinking about leaving the company, make them want to stay. Give them a reason to want to come into work, a lot of your employees are going to leave because of the fact that they aren't treated right. They need more pay, they don't need to have 20 things on their plate. Shorten their work-flow. TREAT YOUR EMPLOYEES WITH RESPECT!!!!! for the Site coordinators: stick up for your employees, whether it is with upper management or patients, stick up for them. Make your employees feel good about themselves. Don't bully your employees, it is time to grow up and stop acting like children.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for taking the time to give us your feedback. We are very sorry to hear that your expectation of working for AAMC has not matched with our goal of being a great place to work. We take these concerns seriously and need to know this information in order to strive to make  AAMC a better organization for all employees. This department is actively working through a transition with the team to create a culture of inclusion and well-being.

reviews.review_pros: The people are wonderful, dedicated, generous and just all around beautiful inside and out.  The team spirit is wonderful, if you are drowning someone will always jump in and help you out.  The benefits are really great!  I had an expensive surgery there and it was completely paid in full!!  That's great insurance.
reviews.review_cons: Hard to get into the job.  I had to walk in with a resume and refuse to leave until I got a job!  it took a little doing but it was well worth it.
reviews.review_summary: Great place to work, it's like a little city in itself...it has everything except a grocery store.  LOL
reviews.review_advice: I know it's all about the money, but it's also all about the employees without which you would make no money.  I have to say that for the most part the management is very fair with it's employees, jeep up the good work.

reviews.review_pros: Ability to work weekends. Most of the employees are very nice. I was given consistent raises. Good, up to date equipment to work with. Excellent location, right off Route 50. Beautiful facility.
reviews.review_cons: Toward the end of my time there bullies were rampant and supervisors didn't take it seriously. A new manager started, who was male. Why are males always the big decision makers is an industry where the majority of employees are female? That never ends well.  After experiencing a minor difficulty with a doctor, I was called in to my manager's office for a write up. He told me that if I didn't perform a sexual act on him that he would fire me. I didn't and he did. I've never told anyone, not even my husband. I think I was in shock at first. Then I was too embarrassed and ashamed to say anything.  For some odd reason, I blamed myself.  This has ruined my life.
reviews.review_summary: I loved my job, and was really good at it, until I was summarily fired.
reviews.review_advice: Watch who you're putting in charge. There are a lot of predators out there.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Your feedback greatly concerns us. Our organization does not tolerate harassment in any form. We have policies in place specific to discrimination and harassment to protect our employees. Please contact Sharon Borland, Manager of Employee Relations at 443-481-1971 so we can further discuss this situation.

reviews.review_pros: Great coworkers who really want to help patients, decent facilities. Luckily, they are still pretty generous with opportunities within the hospital (clinical ladder, paying you for non-mandatory training, transferring within, etc.). Pay is actually very good, although health insurance is ridiculously expensive.
reviews.review_cons: Upper nursing and medical management (who control everything without asking anyone's opinion) only care about numbers. I get how that is very important but the hospital is losing nurses left and right and morale is very low right now. Every unit is short nurses and with a large proportion of new graduates, which is unsafe. The ED is an absolute travesty- they are always extremely short staffed and many nurses do not know how to care for critically ill patients. I'd be afraid to go to my own ED.
reviews.review_summary: Used to be exceptional, now it's going downhill
reviews.review_advice: This used to be a wonderful community hospital- now it's a half rate teaching hospital. Please stop focusing on what's prestigious and remember what's important to patients and your loyal staff.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your comment.  It is true that health care organizations throughout the country are undergoing tremendous change, which includes managing a changing group and number of healthcare candidates.  As you mention, we continue to provide much support to our current nursing staff with our clinical ladder, highly regarded nurse residency, certification bonus and tuition reimbursement and scholarship opportunities.  In addition, we are actively working to attract nurses to the organization through referral bonuses, offering relocation, Open Houses and direct access to nurse recruiters.

reviews.review_pros:
Wellness Initiative (growing)- Ensuring health and wellness of employees and finding ways for them to interact with one another outside of work.
Diversity- You meet a lot of interesting people
Pay is okay
reviews.review_cons:
Benefits have gone down hill over the years

Management can get in over their heads and do not seem to take into consideration the opinions and concerns of those below them. Either you are on-board with the changes or nothing.
reviews.review_summary: It's what you make of it
reviews.review_advice: Consider middle management/lower management opinions that directly impact the facilities that they run. Standardization is not always effective. Time management for implementing new changes needs to be a bit smoother in transition.

reviews.review_pros: AAMC is engaged in employees' success whether it's in career advancement, social wellbeing, financial wellbeing or wellness. Problems that have been to the attention of higher management have been or are being addressed so it doesn't fall on deaf ears. There are lots of employee appreciation activities and celebrations. It's a great place to work.
reviews.review_cons: Employees don't always park where they are assigned and it impacts patients trying to get services. This is especially true in the buildings where most of the doctors offices are.
reviews.review_advice: Hold employees in practices accountable to parking policies and write into contract with non-employed practices they have to abide by the parking policy - including physicians!

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your review!

reviews.review_pros: I met people every day at the hospital with a myriad of emotions such as joy, sorrow, grief, etc.  To be able to assist them, hug them or give an encouraging word is what provides me deep satisfaction and reward.
reviews.review_cons: The downside was department nurses, doctors and techs extremely overworked and exhausted from the demands.  Another downside is quality bedside patient care has been substituted with never ending charting and paperwork and micromanagement.
reviews.review_summary: Bringing hope and sunshine to patients and their family members was my number one priority.
reviews.review_advice: Some advice would be to cease immediately from telling  employees there is no money and that every penny must be saved and every stone unturned to save, save, save. This poverty mentality makes medical staff feel guilty and unmotivated and they eventually look for other employment.  The turnover of nurses is huge due to doubling up on their workload to save money and they are unable to do lunch most of the time or have breaks.

reviews.review_pros: I love the compassion to help patients and family! I feel as if I have my own family at work, yes we may argue here & there but we come right back together, settle our differences and work hard to make the best of everything! There is definitely acknowledgement for hard work. Great benefits, great pay, and opportunity to learn and/or promotion!
reviews.review_cons: None....there is always someone you may encounter that you have an issue with at one point in time AT EVERY JOB. Yet this doesn't make a con for AAMC, I LOVE MY JOB!
reviews.review_advice: Please give me more free meal tickets...I love them...I'm just saying...

review_employer_responses.response_text: We are happy to hear how great your experience has been so far at AAMC. Thank you for your comment and we are glad that you have chosen to be a part of our community here!

reviews.review_pros: Located in Annapolis MD, it's a large, comprehensive hospital without having to drive into Baltimore or DC. Free onsite parking. Consistently receives high patient satisfaction scores.  I have worked here many years and many of my good friends are coworkers.
reviews.review_cons: Have had problems with inappropriate behavior / sexual harassment towards myself and witnessed by others, which was not taken seriously by management. Rather than take legal action, and be associated with a scandal that could negatively impact my career, I am looking for work elsewhere.  Also be aware that there is such a strong push to cut costs that staff is expected to work short staffed rather than allow overtime to cover vacations or sick days.
reviews.review_summary: Love my job, but looking elsewhere.
reviews.review_advice: Even in an industry where the majority of staff is female, don't assume there isn't an old boys' club mentality among some male employees .  This is sad because I love my job.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Your feedback greatly concerns us. Our organization does not tolerate harassment in any form. We have policies in place specific to discrimination and harassment to protect our employees.  Please contact Sharon Borland, Manager of Employee Relations at 443-481-1971 so we can further discuss this situation.

reviews.review_pros:
excellent collaboration with team member and ease of communication and shadowing for learning opportunities.

Generous continuing education opportunities for  classes in house and certifications 
Competitive salaries based on years of experience
Pre set schedule with patient slots for hours worked per day 
Wide variety of specialties available
reviews.review_cons:
Documentation system ( computer software system ) for daily notes , re -evaluations and evaluations
Rotating Saturday schedules  ( mandatory )
reviews.review_advice: Hire more staff as PRN to help fill in for staff off coverage and to also work on Saturday coverage to  minimize hours worked .

reviews.review_pros:
I like working for AAMC, if only I could find a job I like. 
MA's are fun to work with.  
Able to vent to only 1-2 staff with trust.
reviews.review_cons:
Manager is unorganized. No respect. Blames you for negativity, when it's the Manager attitude that makes you the way you are. 
Can't trust the staff. 
Co-workers putting their work on you, can't get your own work done. 
A lot of work no good pay. 
Feel like a puppy dog. 
Lazy co-workers.
reviews.review_summary: Great Hopsital, just can't find a position I like.
reviews.review_advice: YOU NEED MORE TRAINING.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your review.  We recently launched a new management essentials training program for new leaders to ensure that  they are well-equipped to lead their teams.  Our organizational development team also provides many resources for employees on how to improve teamwork and cohesiveness in their departments. We want you to grow  with AAMC, and hope you can find your purpose here. To that end, we have numerous programs designed to help you. Our Purpose Wellbeing team promotes ways that employees can achieve their career goals at AAMC. Events like the internal career fair and other resources have been designed to help you find the best fit for you within AAMC. Please check out the "Learning" tab on our intranet to learn more about what AAMC provides to help its employees expand their education and training.

reviews.review_pros:
Best Paying Hospital Around
Tuition Reimbursement
On-site classes and training
Co-workers are great and considerate
Patients come from a variety of different places in MD, very cultured
reviews.review_cons:
Pathways is sort of the "red headed step child" of AAMC since it is offsite.
The consideration that the hospital gets Pathways doesn't. 

Insurance is very expensive for out of network providers.
reviews.review_advice:
Consider pathways like a pavillion of the hospital.
Even though it is offsite it deserves the same attention the hospital main campus does.

reviews.review_pros: Great health benefits. Friendly staff. My direct supervisors and nurses were helpful and I believe that allowed me to grow into being a really good Patient Care Secretary.
reviews.review_cons: Annapolis is a small town. Many from this town work at this hospital in every area. Do not get caught up in the gossip that may ensue. The initial general orientation was informative, yet it could have been presented in a less monotone and boring manner.
reviews.review_summary: Great learning experience with room for growth.

reviews.review_pros: It is a wonderful environment to work in. My fellow Managers/Supervisor have been  wonderful training and supporting me
reviews.review_cons: To many meetings that keep you from completing your work
reviews.review_advice:
Have a training program and manuals for new hire  Managers and Supervisors
People doing the same job should make the same salary, Being brought in at the same rate from previous practice where you are hourly and get overtime and go to salary working many more hours you are actually take a pay cut.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your review! We are happy to hear that you have felt welcomed and supported by your colleagues and supervisors. We understand the challenges of being a new leader in an organization and provide ongoing training for our leadership. We appreciate feedback and use it to make our  organization a great place to work for all employees.

reviews.review_pros:
-The work was not particularly challenging (pro or con, I guess)
-Overall, the hospital as a whole seems to have good core values and goals.
-Decent pay for a hospital
reviews.review_cons:
-Bureaucracy. Lots of red tape to deal with, unless when dealing with clinical (see next point).
-I understand this is a hospital, but the IS department seemed to be run by the clinical leadership. It seems like the IS leadership are just 'yes men'.
-In IS at least, promotions or transfers seemed to favor external candidates. When internal ones were selected, it seemed to be based more on politics.
-Expensive health insurance, for a hospital!
reviews.review_summary: Bureaucratic and in need of leadership overhaul
reviews.review_advice:
-Not every request from clinical leadership should be taken as law. Some projects can and SHOULD be denied!
-Promote from within!
-There are a handful of older, long time employees with stubborn, toxic personalities.

reviews.review_pros: Flexible schedule, helpful staff and patient rooms equipped with overhead lifts. Every so often bonus checks when fy goals met as an organization, employee recognition dinners.
reviews.review_cons: Benefits a bit sparse and expensive for a hospitals chosen medical benefits.
reviews.review_summary: Overall a great place to work. Staff, nurses, most doctors really friendly and team oriented.
reviews.review_advice: Good job keeping us all in the loop. Please look at some of the redundant middle nursing manager spots. Some of the most unfriendly people in the organization exist here.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your review. Many of us working in the healthcare profession know how challenging and stressful our day to day work can be. There is a universal challenge within healthcare with maintaining quality patient care when there are staffing shortages. The medical center is aware of this burden that is placed on our employees also impacts the care to our patients. We continue look to find ways to help alleviate these issues during these times and appreciate the feedback from our staff.

reviews.review_pros: Staff truly care for their patients. Everyone smiles when you meet them and they attempt to be helpful.
reviews.review_cons: Management will do whatever they can to cut costs. Even if it means targeting employees who make higher salaries so they can hire new staff who make much less.
reviews.review_summary: Treat patients wonderfully, staff, not so much unless they like you.
reviews.review_advice: Treat your staff the way you treat patients

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your feedback. There are many financial challenges that health systems face in todays changing healthcare environment. As a standalone medical center, not attached to a larger health system, we must find best ways to deal with these financial burdens that come with the changes in reimbursement. Despite striving to deliver low cost care, we maintain high quality care and patient satisfaction to meet the needs of the communities we serve.

reviews.review_pros: Closer commute and not a lot of traffic.
reviews.review_cons: I am a veteran and had worked and had worked all along under the umbrella of the Department of Defense. I noticed that private sector or at least where I work here at AAMC that leadership does not really care about their subordinates. Disrespect and arrogance towards subordinates are common practice. Micromanagement also is a common practice which should be a thing of the past. It is creating an unhealthy work environment. So much power struggle is noticeable amongst leaders. reviews.review_pros: I have worked for AAMC for many years. Overall, it is a good place to work. In some ways it is comparable to local hospitals, in some ways not so much. Pros are that most directors/managers will work with your schedule if possible. The overall culture is desirable, however, my unit in particular has low morale, and always has due to a continued increase in demands, and a steady decrease in resources. I have seen many, many colleagues leave and go to other areas of the hospital, so the hospital in general is an OK place to work.
reviews.review_cons: Healthcare benefits are subpar. There are no sick days (some other local hospitals have "sick banks," vacation time must be used, and usually not without penalty). The hospital has continuously decreased leave accumulation (CLB), as well as differentials. However, I'm sure that this sort of thing is common amongst area hospitals. If I was a nurse seeking new employment, I would likely select a different hospital because some nursing floors have done away with nursing assistants (PCTs). Such units include high acuity units, where you may only have 2-3 patients, but they are total care patients who may be upwards of 350+ pounds, and have a lot of needs. Many nurses are experiencing back pain. Management will say "but you have ceiling lifts." True, but how do you visualize the patients posterior skin? Nurses are reliant on neighbor nurses in a poorly constructed floor plan, and it is not uncommon for you and/or your neighbor nurses to have high acuity assignments of their own. I have never seen or heard of a hospital eliminating an entire discipline, risking both patient and staff safety for the sake of budget.  It is a complete divergence from evidence based practice. However, the hospital hired several physicians and nurse practitioners on this particular floor. It's wonderful that medical staff is being increased, but who is going to bathe the patients, turn the patients, take vitals, draw labs, transport the patients to testing, and more? The support staff of course, and the hospital has eliminated many. If you are considering employment on a floor such as the one described, please know that you will be dietary, housekeeping, stocking staff, as well as be expected to care for high acuity patients. It should also be known that this hospital has MAGNET status, and primarily hires BSN prepared nurses.
reviews.review_summary: Overall a OK facility to work for, but...
reviews.review_advice: Hire PCTs, even if just ONE for an entire floor. They are invaluable. They can help with: turning and bathing patients, transporting unstable patients, obtaining equipment in emergencies, and so much more. Local colleges and vocational schools train nursing assistants because their role in the healthcare field is invaluable. I hope to be able to update my review in the near future.

review_employer_responses.response_text: We appreciate your feedback.   Recently we did make a change to an all RN staffing model for our ICU/IMC unit.  With this change we will be increasing the number of RN’s on this unit.  This decision was made based on the acuity of patients and to decrease nurse:patient ratios.   Already we are seeing positive results from the change.  We agree that our Patient Care Technicians are invaluable.  We assisted each technician in finding commensurate employment within the healthcare system.  We know that change can be difficult and encourage you to discuss your concerns with your nursing leadership or Kristin Kowaliw, HR Business Partner.  Keeping the lines of communication open are important with any change.

After experiencing a minor difficulty with a doctor, I was called in to my manager's office for a write up. He told me that if I didn't perform a sexual act on him that he would fire me. I didn't and he did. I've never told anyone, not even my husband. I think I was in shock at first. Then I was too embarrassed and ashamed to say anything.  For some odd reason, I blamed myself.  This has ruined my life.

reviews.review_pros: Some units really have the best teams and nurses and doctors working for them. They made coming to work,worth it.
reviews.review_cons: however for the most part, BUDGET BUDGET BUDGET is all we were hearing recently. They've taken away our employee discount in the cafeteria, the so called "merit increases" are a joke no matter how well you perform and everything is now based on patient satisfaction which is outrageous.  They now are even dictating where employees should park with no regard to which part of the building they work in or safety of the staff!! They expected us to cater to the pts like its a 5 star hotel while making us work understaffed and over worked. Each unit makes up their own holiday policies and procedures for the most part. So if they need you to work a certain holiday, theres no importance given to your seniority. This used to be an great hospital to work at but since they are placing priority on money and not the wellbeing of their staff and patients, it all gone down hill. Every unit I have been on there are staff crying, angry, feeling unappreciated and looking for jobs elsewhere.  I even spoke to the current CNO about safe patient to nurse ratios and she basically said that in the end it was a business and that we were nationally meeting our safety goals. I was floored because she said this in front of a lot of staff members who felt the same way I did. Point is, when your no longer at the bedside and raking in all the money, you tend to forget those that are in the trenches making you that money!! When they place the emphasis back on patient centered care and the wellbeing of those at the beside day after day, maybe they'll stop having such a high turn over rate. Having worked on different units while there, I saw over 25+ employees leave in less than 2 years. Thats a major red flag.
reviews.review_advice: Understand that patients are sicker and 10 times needier now in days and lower nurse to patient/ tech to patient ratios across the whole hospital!! Listen to those who are the heart of the organization!!!appreciate your employees no matter what the position is!!

Thank you for posting. We appreciate your feedback and want to be sure to address your concerns. We’ll provide some high-level detail here, but please feel free to contact your supervisor or HR business partner if you have additional questions.
All AAMC employees are eligible for an annual merit increase based on their performance. You’ll be hearing more about this process later this fall. Turnover is also something we watch closely and it’s one of our True North metrics. Your leader can share more information with you about that. As an organization, we continuously work to evaluate compensation packages, staffing levels, training needs, etc. If you have specific feedback in one of these areas, I encourage you to share that with us at Recruitment@aahs.org. Thank you.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your feedback. AAMC considers its employees to be its most valuable asset. Over the past two years, we have implemented additional programs to help our employees find opportunities within the organization. This includes internal career fairs and Expanding Horizons, which features a work/study program. We also offer tuition assistance, certification bonuses and training and workshops including Microsoft Office, LEAD Academy, management classes, resume writing and interviewing tips. We also encourage you to talk to your supervisor on ways you can advance your career at AAMC.

Medical benefits are expensive and do not cover a lot, even when you are seen at AAMC (example: $150 copay for MRIs and CTs at AA Diagnostics). The benefits are much worse when you see a provider outside AAMC, which is often since AAMC does not offer a wide-range of specialists. 
The tuition reimbursement is only $3,000 for graduate studies - this does not promote higher education for employees.
The various units/departments do not work well together, which negatively impacts not only the employee experience but also the patient experience.
reviews.review_advice: Improved medical benefits will greatly improve employee satisfaction. Also, please take note of how inefficient the workflows are between units/departments because each one acts as if it is an entity by itself and not as part of a larger system.

review_employer_responses.response_text:
We continuously benchmark our benefit plan offerings against other health systems of the same size in an effort to offer a competitive benefits package. Currently, we offer three different medical plans to our part-time and full-time employees. The deductible, copayment and coinsurance amounts vary by plan. We offer these choices because we believe that one medical plan does not fit everyone’s needs and that employees should be able to pick what works best for them. Another way we work to keep the benefit costs down is by having a tiered benefit structure, where our leadership and physicians pay a higher percentage of the premium costs to offset the premiums paid by employees.

As an organization we encourage employees’ growth through training and additional education. In order to provide tuition reimbursement to as many of our full-time and part-time employees as possible, we had to set this annual maximum. In addition to tuition reimbursement, AAMC has many scholarship programs which eligible employees are able to apply to.

If you have concerns about the collaboration between departments, we encourage you to speak to your supervisor.

We recently implemented management essential skills training for all new leaders to ensure that employees have a consistent experience throughout the organization, no matter where they report. AAMC is always working to strengthen our diversity initiative. We know that a diverse organization better represents the communities for which we care.  
It’s our goal to provide employees with affordable benefits that meet their healthcare needs. In fact, employees who hold leadership roles supplement the cost of some of those benefits. There is a tiered cost sharing structure, so that the higher-paid employees pay more than others.

Our employees are integral to our ability to provide the best care to our community and we strive to provide competitive compensation and benefits. In many departments we have clinical/career ladders to provide opportunities to learn and grow while increasing compensation as well.  Recognition of employees, by leaders, patients, families and coworkers is encouraged through several recognition programs which include our H.O.T. cards, the DAISY Award for nursing and the Champion honors for AAMC employees who go above and beyond to provide exemplary service. We also celebrate our tenured employees with a service award celebration every year.

reviews.review_pros: The commute to Anne Arundel Medical Center is very convenient.  There are definitely some good jobs to be had, especially in the clinical environment.  My poor opinion of AAMC is for the most part a reflection on the management; there are some very nice and very talented people who work there.  A fair number of cushy jobs are to be had, especially by those able and willing to play the "game."
reviews.review_cons: Nowhere else have I seen such poor management.  The rot extends from top to bottom.  A VP came down to explain how our CIO had "decided" to leave, "inventing" all sorts of details along the way, when by that point the entire staff knew that the CIO was being forced out:  if you don't want to talk about it, fine, but don't stand there lying to our faces.  A decade ago the hospital was much smaller, but it's grown extremely fast.  It used to be a family of sorts where everyone knew each other, but that doesn't scale well.  Unfortunately, almost everything is accomplished, now, in a back room through this network of relationships, contrary to what stated policy is.  Staff, especially clinical, have been almost exclusively promoted into management despite lack of qualification as the hospital has grown; the result has been massive cost overuns and high turnover.  Turnover in my group (non-clinical) was in excess of 300% a year for over 3 years.  Expectations are not followed through on, promises are not kept, because the hospital does not move cohesively.  A large part of the hospital's success of late is their very committed (and wealthy) donor base; the hospital itself is doing very poorly.
reviews.review_advice: Clean house in middle management.  It would be very painful, but the alternative is the present chaos.  As you know, morale in extremely low, and turnover is very high.  HR has made some ovatures towards the staff, but they won't be received unless there is followthrough from direct management.

reviews.review_pros: Some units really have the best teams and nurses and doctors working for them. They made coming to work,worth it.
reviews.review_cons: however for the most part, BUDGET BUDGET BUDGET is all we were hearing recently. They've taken away our employee discount in the cafeteria, the so called "merit increases" are a joke no matter how well you perform and everything is now based on patient satisfaction which is outrageous.  They now are even dictating where employees should park with no regard to which part of the building they work in or safety of the staff!! They expected us to cater to the pts like its a 5 star hotel while making us work understaffed and over worked. Each unit makes up their own holiday policies and procedures for the most part. So if they need you to work a certain holiday, theres no importance given to your seniority. This used to be an great hospital to work at but since they are placing priority on money and not the wellbeing of their staff and patients, it all gone down hill. Every unit I have been on there are staff crying, angry, feeling unappreciated and looking for jobs elsewhere.  I even spoke to the current CNO about safe patient to nurse ratios and she basically said that in the end it was a business and that we were nationally meeting our safety goals. I was floored because she said this in front of a lot of staff members who felt the same way I did. Point is, when your no longer at the bedside and raking in all the money, you tend to forget those that are in the trenches making you that money!! When they place the emphasis back on patient centered care and the wellbeing of those at the beside day after day, maybe they'll stop having such a high turn over rate. Having worked on different units while there, I saw over 25+ employees leave in less than 2 years. Thats a major red flag.
reviews.review_advice: Understand that patients are sicker and 10 times needier now in days and lower nurse to patient/ tech to patient ratios across the whole hospital!! Listen to those who are the heart of the organization!!!appreciate your employees no matter what the position is!!

review_employer_responses.response_text:
Thank you for your feedback. While we do have to be good stewards of our resources, I can assure you that the wellbeing of our employees is a top priority at AAMC. We have made some recent changes related to benefits as you reference below. These changes are designed to help keep benefits equitable across the health system as we add more locations around the region. Our recent retirement plan enhancements are one example. We are making other changes for employee and patient safety at the request of our employees – the parking updates are part of that effort.

If you have additional concerns you would like to speak to someone about, please contact Marita Kellers at MKellers@aahs.org.

reviews.review_cons: Pay  is quite disappointing - far from market avg. (unlike many other aspects of AAH). Aligned communication can be tricky with so much going on,  there is an expectation to be jack of all trades.
reviews.review_advice: Be mindful of how far goodwill, loyalty and 'going the extra mile' should go, before you reflect on remuneration. Quick to praise (which is nice!) but slow to financially reward.

reviews.review_pros: Some very kind, talented coworkers
reviews.review_cons:
Unfortunately in the time I've been at AAHA, history has negatively repeated itself like clockwork despite a new CEO, many executive-level shakeups, and board members having to show up to the office for a "come to Jesus" culture meeting after roughly half the staff left in a six month period due to internal negligence. In many ways, I feel like I'm in an abusive relationship with AAHA.

Currently, the CEO Garth Jordan is making decisions to cut, introduce, or change programs and initiatives without fully understanding the context, consequences, or all the roles associated with them. Teams have been consolidated into one without clear direction, new job descriptions, or even an understanding of what each person previously did. It's up to us to pick up the pieces along the way. It feels like there's a new, intensely high priority, project introduced every other week with an impossible deadline attached to it. Employees are expected to manage these half-baked ideas on top of insane workloads and often serving on several extracurricular, ineffective "core teams".

These projects are often presented as "fun, blue skies experiments" where we can "be creative and playful". In reality, we're trying to execute someone else's misguided vision with vague or no direction, and circumvent challenges that should have been considered before committing to the project. When we ask "why?" in an attempt to understand the project, we either don't get a full, compelling answer or we're scolded and treated as "problem employees" (or both). 

I think many within leadership are acting out of fear of the board and CEO Garth Jordan. Based on the hostile meetings and micro aggressions I've witnessed, I can't blame them. I understand with any new leadership change there will be growing pains and as an employee I won't agree with every decision made. Gaslighting, intimidation, and ignoring employee concerns, however, is not okay.

Many of us are suffering in silence right now, forced to rely on each other instead of leadership. We were told for months we'd have an anonymous follow-up culture survey distributed in March. Then, in the March all-staff meeting, it was announced this would not be happening and we'd be moving it to the summer instead. Now, we have to wait to have our collective voices heard. It seems AAHA is more interested in giving the CEO more time to fulfill his vision than make room to listen for potential warning signs. 

Most of us are introverts who do not feel comfortable voicing our concerns to our leaders publicly. Some of us don't trust our managers. Garth hosts open office hours but I've already been reviewed negatively by my manager for disagreeing with him in an open forum. If I had the opportunity to take that anonymous culture survey in March, I probably wouldn't even be writing this review. But under the fake smiles and excitement for "a new start", AAHA is breaking employees's spirits at an alarming rate.

For those interested, it's worth noting that AAHA's "commitment" to diversity, equity, and inclusion is entirely performative lip service bogged down by the gluttonous weight of complacency. With so much time, effort, and money being wasted on dozens of competing priorities, it's very telling that the things that actually matter are being left to get lost in red tape.
reviews.review_advice: Stop burying your head in the sand.

review_employer_responses.response_text: Thank you for your feedback. AAHA values all our employees and we are committed to the continuous improvement of our internal culture. The reference to the culture survey is outdated as our Executive Team recently chose to move forward with the survey in its quarterly frequency. With that opportunity, please offer your feedback as Glassdoor is not a venue where we can have an open dialogue. Likewise, the entire Executive Team supports a safe space for any/all constructive and crucial conversations. Please take advantage of our willingness to listen. We can all learn from each other when we enter conversations with open minds, open hearts, and an eye toward the new future we are designing for our organization.

reviews.review_pros: This place has undergone a cultural overhaul within the past couple of months. While the info in earlier reviews is accurate, leadership has (finally) done a great job of getting rid of toxic employees in leadership positions and taking in employee feedback regarding what needs to change.
reviews.review_cons: There is still much to be done, but we are on the right path. The one comment I have to address from other reviews is regarding salary. For some reason it's regularly lost on people that AAHA is a NOT-FOR-PROFIT association. While we do take in revenue, that revenue is put right back into our programs and initiatives. Our only goal at the end of the fiscal year is not to be negative, $-wise. Of course everyone would love to make more money, but if you go to work for a nonprofit or not-for-profit company for the money, you're in the wrong place.
reviews.review_summary: On the right path; lots of room to grow
reviews.review_advice: Continue on our current path; continue listening to the feedback from your employees.

reviews.review_pros: They offer good benefits to employees
reviews.review_cons: Top down leadership is actually hurting employees emotional well being. It takes away the opportunity for employees to use their talents. So the talent frequently walks out the door. Decisions that affect many are made by a few. Due to this, the turn over is really bad which always adds stress to the employees still there.
reviews.review_advice: Listen to your employees. ALL of your employees. Seek their input.

reviews.review_pros: Great work environment. Flexible schedule

reviews.review_pros: Benefits are decent; get to work from home 4 times a month, have good healthcare coverage and can wear comfortable clothes. They're getting better about closures and letting people know ahead of time.
reviews.review_cons:
Above everything, pay is so incredibly laughable here; that is, unless you happen to be here for a while (10+ years) to where you get paid an absurd amount for doing (comparatively) not much. 

Everything else besides the pros listed are bad. Management can't see that they're driving good people out the doors, and turnover is becoming higher and higher. I'm about ready to walk out the door because the salary is so pitiful compared to the amount of work we do. Pay your employees what the market dictates they're worth. Don't insult me with a tiny raise for "cost of living"-which, by the way, is nowhere NEAR the cost of living in Denver. Laughable!

Communication is pretty bad, pay is laughable to say the LEAST, and people are honestly miserable here. There's so much backstabbing, gossiping and general annoyance here. I don't know if the E-team knows this or not. So many people I've talked to are literally ready to leave AAHA at any moment. The reason they stay is because they're concerned with their friends and the workload they would inevitably have to take on if they did leave; since AAHA apparently doesn't like to hire enough people for the job.

The workload constantly goes up and up and up without any increase in pay. Yet, we spend tens of thousands of dollars on initiatives and programs that don't net us any money in return. But hey, at least we get to work from home while we make literally 35% less than the same or lesser job in the Denver metro area. Pitiful and insulting.
reviews.review_advice:
Communication is so terrible! Upper management can't seem to figure out their employees for some reason. They refuse to hire more people when the work is very clearly there. AAHA just hired a marketing person who is apparently already behind on work. The creative team is frustrated and constantly bombarded with tasks, the Learning department is working their butts off and can't gain traction with more projects and things being off-loaded on them, Pubs is down a person, Jan's sponsorship team is down a person, MX is down several people, and yet no one gets any raises...that's rather bizarre, don't you think? People leaving, yet the work that's being left on others' plates doesn't get recognized? My work has easily doubled and...nothing! Not even a thank-you from management, and certainly not a penny increase thanks to James and his hounding financials. 

People aren't numbers. Pay us what we're worth and you'll see magic happen before your eyes.

reviews.review_advice: Pull your heads out, and get rid of the problem. Let us get back to actually caring and make AAHA about animals and not the little man's ego.

reviews.review_pros: Starting employment with great PTO and an easy way to request it. Flexible hours. Always busy with something to do and there is something new every day. Lots of travel available and most of the people you work with are great. You get your travel calendar early so you can plan ahead. Easy to work from your computer when traveling. Good location for the office. The annual convention is a great experience but a lot of work.
reviews.review_cons: There is a review on here that says you don't have to "wait your turn" for responsibility. That is only true for a very special group of people. The rest of us do wait with no explanation as to why others get perks and the rest of us don't. People are put into leadership positions with NO training whatsoever and minor qualifications while others don't even get to voice their ideas or opinions.
reviews.review_summary: Great Benefits, Good Coworkers, Bad Leadership
reviews.review_advice: Nobody feels they can voice their concerns because there is very little confidentiality. Have a better open door policy so people don't have to come on glass door to be heard. Hire people based on what their work resume says, not because they were an eagle scout in high school. Promote people who know what it means to be a leader. Department heads, TRUST your teams. If there is someone on your team you feel wouldn't follow your leadership, it means YOU are in the wrong somewhere. Not them.

reviews.review_pros: Office location, dynamic environment, clear expectations and communication
reviews.review_cons: Lack of upward mobility, uneven distribution of work, weak relationship between staff and membership

reviews.review_pros:
Great employee benefits include once a month additional time off on Fridays, flexible work schedule, great health benefits and employee benefits, fun office culture where employees are offered opportunities that are not offered elsewhere to work with industry leaders. 

The Interim President & CEO is great about working with staff to develop professionally, and is open to ideas to make the work environment better. Has an open door policy, and is great at communicating to all employees. Access to executives like this is a huge plus, and is not common at other places I have worked.  Leadership also is great about supporting our team in all aspects. Is willing to listen to employees career wants and fit them in new opportunities to gain experience outside their department. 

Coworkers and executives alike are great people and professionals to work with.
reviews.review_cons: Lots of travel in certain roles, and less in others but leadership is willing to work with you to accommodate your preference on how much travel you take on.
reviews.review_summary: Great Office Culture and Employee Benefits
reviews.review_advice: Continue to build a great working culture.

reviews.review_pros:
The executive leadership (Interim President & CEO Rachel Humphrey and Chief of Staff Kathryn Stone) could not be any more supportive. They genuinely care about everyone on staff and are happy to serve as mentors/guides.

Because it's such a small company, you have the opportunity to work on large projects and take on significant responsibility right out of the gate instead of "waiting your turn." Everyone is so busy that there's no time for micromanaging, which is wonderful.

The culture is great - everyone on staff truly gets along (super rare) and works together to accomplish seemingly impossible goals. Plus, the work schedule is flexible.
reviews.review_cons:
The Board of Directors is too involved in daily operations. There are some political landmines that require navigation because of their over-involvement. 

Work-life balance tends to get a little lost. We were severely understaffed for the amount of work expected; most people on staff cared about helping and making things happen, which tended to require extra hours.

reviews.review_pros: Helped to broaden my horizons on the world we live in today.
reviews.review_cons: In my opinion, this company is terrible! I've never worked for such a BS place in my life. They call themselves "pro-business" and try to be "the voice for hoteliers" but what that really means is, they are advocating to see the rich get richer and the poor get poorer – “allegedly”. If you are thinking about working here make sure you read through their magazine. Understand that this is a pro-Trump organization-“allegedly,” so be sure you read the website carefully. Aside from the politics, the office lacks structure/control, meaning the employees are over worked and under paid – “allegedly”. "Fast paced" really means, you are about to work more hours than you want, and if you don't, be prepared to play catch up and get burned out “allegedly”. A lot of the employees are cool and fun to talk to, but there are a select few who seem to be just putting on to save face. I experienced pompous and snooty attitudes from a select few. Bottom line is, only work here if you are desperate. Everything is very calculated and shady – “allegedly.” ^ My opinion^ Just saying! Good Luck!

reviews.review_pros: Leadership recognizes the importance of a work-life balance.  The iCEO is approachable and firmly believes in her team's professional development. reviews.review_pros: AAHRPP has great retirement benefits.  The staff is very diverse, women, LGBTQ, and POC.  People there know HRP regulations. There were great opportunities to network with officials at top universities. They do great work in promoting and protecting rights in human research.
reviews.review_cons:
While management knows their industry, they do not know how to run a business and thrives on gossip. While there, management rarely worked in the office, which lead to a disconnect between staff and management. I was excited to work there, but by the end of my time there I felt I was being bullied at work by superiors. There were no  conflict resolution mechanisms for dealing with potential problems. 

In less than a calendar year (Jan - October), AAHRPP lost half of it's hardworking, dedicated staff. 

Most of these issues come down to lacking management skills and business experience.
reviews.review_summary: Great mission, but lacking in application.
reviews.review_advice: Business administration and management are essential to running a functioning business. Professional development is important, so get certified in non-profit management and/or take some staff management classes. AAHRPP has a brilliant staff, but no one knows how to manage them. I really believe that the staff is amazing, but really just needs those business and management skills to have a thriving, rich work culture for everyone there. However, I'm not optimistic that it will happen.

reviews.review_pros: Meaningful, honest work. Reasonable case loads. Flexible schedules and ample time off. Very small agency, so you become somewhat of a family. Everyone is really passionate about what they do. Lots of opportunity for professional development through workshops, trainings, etc. There is also a ton of opportunity to interact with other agencies in the county so you end up networking with a lot of important figures in homelessness prevention and mental health.
reviews.review_cons: Because of the small size of the agency (staff and budget-wise), there is little to no opportunity for advancement. Due to the intimate setting, it was sometimes difficult not to take things other staff did or said personally. Small staff also means that there was no one to handle non-business hour phone calls from clients. It's critical to have strong boundary setting skills in order to avoid burnout.
reviews.review_advice: Keep growing the board of directors, keep fundraising, and keep putting yourself out there.

reviews.review_pros: Small workforce, close employee bonds, work together easily, positive energy, staff easily accommodated for time off or interests, staff input listened to and application used, great support for both personal and professional growth.

reviews.review_cons: It is a slave factory, only poor Asians who need a visa support will stay. It’s very lucky for me to finally find another job and be able to leave here. During the past quarter, 3 out of 4 new employees chose to quit, only one stayed for visa problem. Other engineers were trying to find a new job secretly. From the first day I worked here I suffered, I worked from 9 am to 11 pm, the manager assigned a lot of tasks everyday and checked them out suddenly, when he found anyone of these many tasks hasn’t been completed, he will criticize and abuse you fiercely. So engineers had started to learn and delayed every projects and they don’t care for the abuse anymore. The manager parachuted in from Shanghai wants everyone to do overtime, only Americans can say no. Asian engineers in the production department have to work 12-16 hours/day and they are forced to work full day long on Saturdays and sometimes on Sundays. Considering the low wages the company pays for an engineer, the hourly wage is much lower than the technicians’.(less than $13/h). Not to mention the manager just have the credit and took no responsibility for any decisions, he himself wants engineers to make final decisions, if bad things happen, he takes no responsibility at all.  What’s worse, the HR leaks the bad reviews to the manager. Everyday is a torture here. God bless my poor colleagues find better jobs.

reviews.review_pros: I cannot think of any pros at all
reviews.review_cons: The managers expect to suck up until the last drop of your blood. One of my co-workers is forced to work from 10 am. to 2 am every single day without overtime pay and he is set up as a role model that other engineer and technician should learn from. In this company, managers show no respect to engineers and technicians, they think they are GODs, workers are underclass, they mercifully grant workers some small money to buy food and workers should work for managers’s promotion and stocks until death. PTO are seldom allowed, “ Only we diligent managers have the right to have PTO, all of you sitting here do not have the right to have PTO!” The senior manager said this in the morning meeting to the engineers in public. Managers only care about their own credits, none of them matters lives of others. Tons of position offers were sent to candidates during the past few months, not a single one came to work in the end. Managers tried every trick to cheat candidates into coming to work for the company, but failed all the time. It’s not even a good choice for people who needs a working visa. The company doesn’t do a working visa application process for employees who starts his or her first day from January to March, you have to work for the company for many months before April. Some new hires waste almost a year waiting for the company to start their H1B working visa application. Unfortunately, according to the last H1B lottery results, ZERO of the six Chinese employees won, the attorney of this company told that all of them failed in lottery. It’s total a waste of time to work for this company because it can give you nothing but a greedy manager, a bullying environment, a 60 hours plus working hour per week, an extremely low pay wage, no promotion opportunity, almost no PTO allowed, no 401K match, heavily increasing workload month by month, a so-called “ competitive environment “ set up by the senior manager in which co workers hate and bad mouth each other......

Good job security. They wont fire you even you do absolutely NOTHING.

reviews.review_cons:
This will be a long list:
Shady performance review and promotion system. Engineers with different job descriptions are compared with each other. By that logic, you should be comparing that guy that cleans CEOs car with cleaning ladies. And this "normalization algorithm" is just shady as *.
Now they are even implementing a special performance grade just for R&D. If base salary for RD is already higher than other engineers, why do you need a special grade? 
Getting a promotion does not guarantee a raise(like, seriously?)
Cronyism. Bunch of people does not know anything but playing politics.
Terrible training system.
Some departments not carrying their weight (looking at you, facilities and QC). 
Upper managements setting unrealistic goals with no extra resources. 
Incompetent lower managements. This is however somewhat due to upper managements like to micro manage everything.
Low base salary. I heard new hires are getting better offers these days, but it is nowhere near to being competitive.
Overall poor planning and slow decision making.
Dead weights that handles crucial and time sensitive tasks not delivering even once, but never called out nor corrected. Meanwhile people that have been performing extremely well is asked to work even more overtime.

Just to name a few from the top of my head.
reviews.review_summary: It can be so much more
reviews.review_advice:
Get rid of dead weights. You can't ask people to work smart when half of your employees are not working nor being smart.
If you have to ask people to post good reviews on this website, you should be really thinking what is wrong with the company. 
All you have to do is to simply gather criticisms from all employees and you should be able to see a pattern.

reviews.review_pros:
- Despite being a public company, the company very much like a startup.  This means that there is a lot of opportunity to grow and learn.  The growth rate of the company is high and this means that if you execute, you can learn a lot.  
- The company gives a lot of resources to learn (online classes, UH and Rice classes, etc.)
- A lot of people have worked here for a long time so there is a sense of community and people helping each other.
reviews.review_cons: Because the company operates like a startup and has strong growth, there is a high expectation to execute and get things done.  If you're looking for a job that you can cruise through, this isn't a job for you.

reviews.review_pros: Lots to do, lots to learn, good for fresh graduates and fast learners
reviews.review_cons: Very unprofessional performance review system, very UNFAIR ratings, if you rate yourself different from your boss, your final score will be greatly penalized. If you are lucky enough to rate yourself similar to your boss, HR will adjust your boss rating and you will get the same low score. Basically the HR and management are manipulating the ratings and promotions of employees. As a result, good employees pissed off every year every time when it came to review.
reviews.review_advice: Revamp performance review system, treat people fairly

reviews.review_pros: Only good thing here is, people are nice.
reviews.review_cons:
Company never rewards people as they should have. Company underpays a lot for most of the positions and I know lots of people here never got promotions after they worked more than five years for the company. Someone got a promotion on the title but nothing in terms of salary.  There is a joke inside the company, "Fulltime job, parttime salary"

When economy was down, the company cut 10% of the salary for all engineers and above and asked their employees to work 2 hrs overtime in force without paying any extra even if there was actually no work out there. So people ended up sitting in front of their computers, doing nothing but staring at their monitors. 

In 2009, they laid off 50% of the people and when they rehired some of them back, they only gave 70% of their prior salary. Company also tried to save cost by cutting benefits, not only the deductable is now incredibly higher, but employees even had to pay for their own insurance. If you have family with two kids, you need to pay at least 600 USD a month for the insurance. 

Company has very serious discriminations against people who don't speak and read English very well. If you are not good at English, company won't go with a standard procedure to make you pass probation simply because they don't want to give you a raise at all. However, for those who were born here or know how to complain, it will a totally different story. 
 
The workload is heavy and very stressful to meet the deadline. On average, an engineer needs to stay one more hour everyday and sometimes work on the weekend as well, of course, without anything extra. But, no matter how hard you worked, how many contributions you made, you won't get any bonus, nothing, not a penny.

I've already got out of this ugly place whereas I am sorry for my friends who still work there, especially those who were treated unfairly.  For those who are going to be here, please stay out of this company whatever there is another choice.
reviews.review_summary: Don't work for the company if you have any other choice.
reviews.review_advice: Please don't be short vision and start to value the persons that worked their heads off for you. Be fair and don't make the workspace full of this stupid nepotism anymore.

reviews.review_pros: I felt I was paid fairly and benefits were generous. There is a lot of opportunity for improvement of current processes, so there is always something to do. The company is profitable and growing, but the employees have become slaves of the shareholders.  Positions are always available due to constant turnover. This used to be decent company to work for until 2018, but new management ruined everything.
reviews.review_cons:
Turnover has always been a huge problem. Newly appointed managers have killed morale for several departments, causing many tenured employees to walk away. The yearly turnover rate for 2019 was 90%. Employees in nearly every department get overloaded trying to replace departures.

All of the recent manager hires in Longview have been unaccepably bad. Instead of promoting knowledgeable people from within, loud mouths with no industry experience were brought in. They never listen to their employees and constantly state "This worked at my last company, so this is how we'll do it." When the ideas inevitably fail, the managers throw whoever they can under the bus and never accept accountability for their poor decisions. The lack of knowledge of AAON products and refrigeration among the managers is insulting. THIS IS A CULTURE WHERE KNOWLEDGE DOESN'T MATTER.

Many departments are arranged very poorly. One is team is being managed by someone who has a job function completely unreleated to what his subordinates do. Certain departments are filled with underqualified personnel or have poor leadership. These departments create endless problems for everyone else.
reviews.review_advice:
Create a culture where knowledge matters. All of the recently appointed managers love bossing other people around, but are clueless about the tasks, processes, and machines their people work with. Managers who just tell people what do and are unwilling and incapable of helping their people must be replaced. No one should EVER be appointed a manager in an HVAC manufacturing facility that doesn't have HVAC experiece.

Create a culture of positivity instead of one of fear. The 90% turnover rate is due to people's dissatisfaction with their supervisors and managers ALMOST EXCLUSIVELY. Upper management needs to recognize this and hold their managers accountable. Employees at every level are told they will be replaced if they do not perform. This creates a culture of fear, and it clearly is not working. Supervisors need to partner with their employees to help them accomplish objectives instead of threatening them and doing nothing to help.

reviews.review_advice: Start focusing more on employee well-being and less on minutely increasing profits. Before long there won't be enough knowledgeable employees to produce those profits.

reviews.review_cons: Lacks Direction. US versus them mentality. Too many engineers. Huge disconnect between upper management and employees. HR is a mess. You don't feel valued as an employee. High rate of turnover. They start several projects, but very few are finished correctly or at all. Lack of trust between management/ employees. Low morale. Arbitration clause part of employment agreement.
reviews.review_advice: You need to get out there and really pay attention to what's going on on the floor. There is potential for this company to be something great, if there was a culture of trust between management and employees. There is such a high rate of turnover, there is constantly a beginners learning curve in place. Everyone is fearful for their jobs because no one is made to feel important, regardless of skill level or experience. Everyone is lead to believe they are easily replaceable, leading to low morale. Good employees who stay are given more responsibilities, while raises and overlooked. Every departments pay rate has been posted publicly, leading to distrust between employees. You never discuss what you make with another person-why would you post that?

reviews.review_pros: New, clean and up to date Warehouse with great working equipment and Employees. Everyone seems to work very well together to complete job task and work production orders. And after 6 months the company give you a sign on bonus with a lot of training and upgrade courses the company will pay for. A lot of room to grow and move up in pay and skill.
reviews.review_cons: Point system with no room to change job for 1 year.
reviews.review_summary: Warehouse/ Production picking high end electrical parts and motors, including mother boards and switches.
reviews.review_advice: To many different Supervisors to deal with, all with different ways to complete same job tasks at hand, this is due different day and night shift work through the week leaving plenty of room for mistakes with data entry and material handling and theft.

reviews.review_pros: A small company that is constantly improving.
reviews.review_cons:
Turnover rate of employees is extremely high for a multitude of reasons. 1. The pay is very low, especially for engineers. 2. They treat their lower level employees like teenagers that need to be constantly monitored and punished for bad behavior with no benefits for being a good employee.  I have seen many people who were good employees and worked very hard for the company fired for coming in a bit late a few times. Obviously tardiness is undesirable, but the benefit of the employee to the company should be considered before firing is even an option.  

Having said that, since the change over from Scott Absjornson as president to Sam Neale the relationship between management and the employees has improved significantly, but there is still a long way to go before it is on par with average companies of its size.
reviews.review_summary: Terrible Turnover Rate, Treats lower level employees like dirt.
reviews.review_advice: Remove or adjust the attendance points system. While it may seem to weed out people with tardiness issues, but it is costing you employees who have been focused and hardworking otherwise.

reviews.review_advice: Stop getting in the way of the flow of information. Know your role and don't step on other departments' toes.

reviews.review_advice: Think about employee moral instead of how you can line your own pockets more. Give annual raises and not with company stock. And, when you give something to an employee to entice him or her to be hired in the first place, don't take it back form them once they have been hired such as Doc-In-the-Box and Free generic Medicines. This doesn't set well with employees. Don't force people to take a position that you need them for by forcing your will on them by saying you either take this job or loose the one you currently have either way. Poor Management Skills!

reviews.review_pros: Interesting product produced . Unique machinery to work on. Overtime opportunities available. 401K. Quartly Profit Sharing. Personal/ Children Health insurance.
reviews.review_cons: Lacks Direction. US versus them mentality. Too many engineers. Huge disconnect between upper management and employees. HR is a mess. You don't feel valued as an employee. High rate of turnover. They start several projects, but very few are finished correctly or at all. Lack of trust between management/ employees. Low morale. Arbitration clause part of employment agreement.
reviews.review_advice: You need to get out there and really pay attention to what's going on on the floor. There is potential for this company to be something great, if there was a culture of trust between management and employees. There is such a high rate of turnover, there is constantly a beginners learning curve in place. Everyone is fearful for their jobs because no one is made to feel important, regardless of skill level or experience. Everyone is lead to believe they are easily replaceable, leading to low morale. Good employees who stay are given more responsibilities, while raises and overlooked. Every departments pay rate has been posted publicly, leading to distrust between employees. You never discuss what you make with another person-why would you post that?

reviews.review_cons: Nothing.

reviews.review_pros: I enjoyed my work there, and I was given broad authority to develop my applications.
reviews.review_cons:
Employee appreciation was high when I came onboard. There was profit share, sales incentives, and occasional lunches to boost moral. In the 6 years I was there, I saw these get slowly reduced until they were eventually all eliminated. No raises. If someone asked for a raise, they were told they could be replaced by someone new for the same pay.

There is high employee turnover because of a Point System for hourly workers. After a certain number of points, an employee is terminated - whether they are a good worker or a bad one. If you have a wreck coming into work and you are over 30 minutes late, you are automatically maxed out on your points for the year.

Company owned insurance is bad. One of the managers had a motorcycle wreck that broke his back. AAON refused to pay his medical bills, stating that motorcycle riding fell under "risky behavior." Another woman in accounting was diagnosed with cancer and went to the hospital for treatment. The company was fast to put her on Long Term Leave (non-paid time off). Everyone's insurance payments come out of their paychecks, so when she did not pay her premiums, AAON dropped her quick. She died in the hospital.

AAON's attitude towards employees is not just towards hourly employees, but extends to salaried positions, too.  The Production Manager busted his tail up there, but he was let go when a new product line did not start production when the new Company President wanted. They didn't care that the parts were on backorder. The Quality Control Manager was let go because the President said, "Every employee is responsible for quality." Lol - yeah, who is going to hold your low income employees (illegal Mexicans and pot smokers from the hood) to your quality standards?
reviews.review_advice: Take care of your employees.

reviews.review_pros: Profit sharing every quarter. Hours are from 5 am to 3 pm.

You will never get promoted, a raise, stock options, or your own office even if you're promised these things.  It's the worst place you could work for...anywhere else would be better! The Human Resources department is virtually non-existent, as well.
reviews.review_summary: Worst company i've ever worked for!
reviews.review_advice: Don't lie to your employees about salary, job duties, responsibilities, and benefits.  Make sure you hire people that are fit for the job instead of assuming they will just "catch-on" even if they have no experience doing the job when it requires years of previous experience.

reviews.review_pros: A small company that is constantly improving.
reviews.review_cons:
Turnover rate of employees is extremely high for a multitude of reasons. 1. The pay is very low, especially for engineers. 2. They treat their lower level employees like teenagers that need to be constantly monitored and punished for bad behavior with no benefits for being a good employee.  I have seen many people who were good employees and worked very hard for the company fired for coming in a bit late a few times. Obviously tardiness is undesirable, but the benefit of the employee to the company should be considered before firing is even an option.  

Having said that, since the change over from Scott Absjornson as president to Sam Neale the relationship between management and the employees has improved significantly, but there is still a long way to go before it is on par with average companies of its size.
reviews.review_summary: Terrible Turnover Rate, Treats lower level employees like dirt.
reviews.review_advice: Remove or adjust the attendance points system. While it may seem to weed out people with tardiness issues, but it is costing you employees who have been focused and hardworking otherwise.

reviews.review_pros: AAON is a large company. So it has a lot of diversity, culture and creativity. We are well taken care of at AAON, and the CEO has direct control over the operations of his business. You can be sure the people who are hired have sufficient qualification for their job position.

ALL "C" level management, and 80% of mid-level mgt are incompetent; nepotism rules. Incompetent to the point of being ridiculous. Often, that goes hand in hand with theatrical stupidity. Colleagues would start laughing when I simply said who my manager was; no other comments were necessary.

A lot of rank-and-file staff is also unprofessional. If you're good, you'll end up doing your job and theirs. And you'll not be recognized for it.
They will use you for their political purposes.
They're short-staffed.

Tech best practices, policies, run-books, etc. are mostly nonexistent, and when they exist, they're rarely followed or enforced.
Most projects have no managers.
Technologies that you'll be working with are mostly outdated.
The turnover rate in IT is roughly 50% over a 2 year period. That should tell you everything you need to know.
Did I mention that they're incompetent, and they lie?
