The old was trying to work with the new, but the new just railroaded us. They claim to be transparent but we don't know what is going on unless you are part of the "in crowd". Disappointing.
reviews.review_advice: Wake-up and realize that we are people who are here to contribute to the mission, grow, and make a living. Stop bullying us and encourage us.

reviews.review_pros: AAOS is a great place to work and it continues to get better every day. Building a new culture is challenging and the AAOS Leadership Team is doing a great job of communicating and leading the way toward a Member Driven organization. New leadership cares deeply, shares their vision and always working to empower the staff. The mindset is innovative, and the future is very bright.
reviews.review_cons: Unfortunately, scant remnants of legacy thinking run strong within a couple of pockets within the organization; however, the tides are shifting. Continuing to create an accountable culture takes empathy and hard work. However, the hard work of change is worth the investment.
reviews.review_summary: A Great Place to work - AAOS is on the right track
reviews.review_advice: We appreciate your resilience.  Thank goodness you're here and continuing to foster an environment with a Growth Mindset.  Please stay the course and continue to attract the best diverse talent to support our Members and their Patients.

reviews.review_pros: There are so many things that make me feel lucky to work at AAOS.  To start, 2020 was awful personally, yet work was a place that made me feel in control and secure.  Our CEO sent these weekly emails to employees telling us exactly what he was thinking, how he was feeling and how the Academy was handling the pandemic and the other tragedies of 2020. And he’s continued to send these messages and we know we’ll hear things before they’re put in place – the openness in communication at AAOS makes me feel calmer.  In a year where many people lost their jobs, we got to add teammates and add new benefits, even in the middle of a pandemic.  We pulled together as a team and worked really hard to do what we needed to do and that makes me proud.  We found ways to stay connected, have fun and learn more about each other.  When I talk with my friends and family about AAOS, and hear about their own work experiences over the last year, it reaffirms for me what I already knew… AAOS is a very special place to work!
reviews.review_cons: Nothing that I can think of
reviews.review_advice: Keep up the good work.

reviews.review_pros: Yearly annual conference is great
reviews.review_cons: Minimal room for professional growth

reviews.review_pros: I truly don't understand where some of these reviewers are coming from.  AAOS is a well-managed organization that is trying to do its best for its constituency -- mainly its membership but also its staff.  Yes, the organization has changed in the last few years, of necessity -- are we run more like a business than in the past?  Yes, because we have to be fiscally sustainable in order to do our best for our members.  Our values are sound; our practices are sound.  Staff is valuable and valued.  I believe that some of the individuals having the biggest issues are those who have never worked for another organization and have no perspective or context about some of the things AAOS has had to and is trying to do to remain the viable business we are.  The Academy has managed incredibly effectively through a universally-challenging year, with no layoffs, no salary cuts, and no benefits cuts.  Communication from leadership is good and continues to improve; in fact, employee surveys from this year show how much improvement employees have seen in that and many other areas.
reviews.review_cons: It is frustrating to know there are still employees who seem to want to undermine the progress AAOS is trying to make.  Is the organization perfect?  No, but please name one that is.
reviews.review_summary: What's with all the negative reviews?!?
reviews.review_advice: Continue the good work.

reviews.review_pros: Competitive salary and outstanding benefits.
reviews.review_cons: The recent organizational 'flattening' makes it even more difficult to get promoted. Many talented staff have either left or been suddenly let go over the past two years due to leadership and culture change. It's become an increasingly tough work environment where even the most competent and proficient managers fear for their jobs daily.
reviews.review_summary: It's hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel for this organization.
reviews.review_advice: Look beyond your favored few and recognize and reinforce the value of your entire team.

reviews.review_pros: My peers were amazing and I miss them.
reviews.review_cons: Incredible talent has either left or been let go for non-conformance in droves over the last couple years. Huge brain drain. Senior management is artificial smiles, nervous laughs and entirely self-absorbed.
reviews.review_summary: If you choose to work here, you won't stay long.

reviews.review_pros: Senior Management and Executive positions, as well as their hand-picked favorites, get away with whatever they want! This includes nepotism, incompetence, rash decisions to just generate revenue or "beat budget", harassment and mistreatment of other staffers, out and out lying to inferiors, and numerous other behavioral issues resulting in rampant misconduct. Recently a new system of "organizational flattening" was put into effect, under the guise of raising compensation of skilled and valued staff. It appears the “skilled and valued staff” tend to be in these SMT and ELT positions. But don't worry! Block parties, staff celebrations, company sponsored happy hours, mismanagement that works in your favor, and slightly above mediocre salaries will buy the complacency of most!
reviews.review_cons: Leadership lacks knowledge and skills on executing well-informed decisions for the business and actively erodes member benefits, revered programs, and collaboration/partnerships with other ortho societies for the sake of profits. AAOS took just 14 days prior to its big meeting to cancel it in the mean time considering putting both its membership and staff at risk amidst flu and COVID-19 epidemics insisting on holding its annual meeting. Handshake free with extra hand sanitizer... That should work right? Unless Mickey contracted it, the COO felt there would be no problems Board meetings are closed, only allowing the attending members to hear the voices of the executives and approved staff members, safely shielding them from hearing any other voices, opinions, and accurate accounts of the business.
reviews.review_advice: Look for another place to benefit from your talents; that's what I'm currently doing.

reviews.review_pros: Co-workers were kind, good people and fun to be around. It was nice to adjust my hours.
reviews.review_cons: The toxic management and super clicky hierarchy. No one is safe... no matter how hard you work. Being thrown under the bus, happened regularly. Looking back, the best thing that ever happened was being let go. The 5th floor is nothing but backstabbing, rumors, and favoritism. I dreaded going to the office every day. Also: Be careful, sometimes the ones who come off nicest, sweetest or "really want you to succeed" are really just sticking a target on your back.
reviews.review_advice: None. they won't listen anyway.

reviews.review_pros:
Excellent volunteer and leadership 
Nice treats  and parties
reviews.review_cons:
This place is the worst place I’ve worked in 20+ years of working- including my awful stint at A fast food joint at 16. Management lies to your face about the nature of your job, co- workers refuse to help with complex initiatives, and they also lie to volunteers about their ability to deliver on initiatives. Not only do they lack appreciation for experience but education and industry/ professional  standards are undervalued and ignored. Many promises but little execution.

Many workers are getting chronic illnesses and other health problems because of the toxic environment. I wish I could say that the parties and treats were a bonus. They  are used to placate for poor culture and  lack of honesty.
reviews.review_advice: Too many to detail here.

reviews.review_pros: Our members/volunteers are the best!
reviews.review_cons:
- Lies and incompetence at the top
- A very short-sighted attempt to force business models that worked elsewhere into a completely different environment, without thinking through whether these models are viable
- Complete disregard of history and culture; in fact, blind contempt towards history and culture.  Can you build a skyscraper while neglecting the foundation or the soil on which it is supposed to stand?
- Lies and incompetence at the top
reviews.review_summary: I was hopeful and open to changes; I am sadly disillusioned
reviews.review_advice: Haven't you done enough damage?

reviews.review_pros:
1. Many members volunteer their time and are fantastic to work with and care about the staff.

2. Great benefits including vacation, flexible hours, compressed work works, and 1-2 remote workdays per week.

3. Management efforts to move the organization forward (unfortunately, however, this has been painful).

4. Walking distance of several places to grab lunch, etc.

5. Nice, newer building.

6. If you are fortunate with who is your direct supervisor(s), your work will be acknowledged. Unfortunately, many are not so lucky.
reviews.review_cons:
1. At one time, this headline would have said: “Run, Don’t Walk TOWARDS the AAOS.” Unfortunately, the environment is very toxic. I hope that this changes as AAOS used to be a great place to work.

2. When the new CEO and COO started, many agreed that changes were needed to keep AAOS moving into the future and looked forward to being a part of the changes. Unfortunately, the promises of transparency and communication have not been honored. Yes, there are all-employee meetings, but the rumor mill has made these a laughing stock. Upper management may report to the directors, etc. what their plans are, but in many cases, this information doesn’t get disseminated.

3. Management says work-life balance but it not a reality (except perhaps for themselves). Depending on your area, you will have un-realistic deadlines, too much work on your plate, or will simply need to get your work done as you were in meetings or training sessions (including mandated HR sessions).

4. The restructuring has led to a lot of long-term employees being let go. Which has caused a lot of uncertainty and the feeling that knowledge, experience, and connections are not valued AND resentment when newer employees are favored or glorified. However, long-term employees also often don’t appreciate the fresh perspective that newer employees have.

5. Some of the new management doesn’t know how to be managers or don’t even know what their area does. This lack of knowledge has led to some employees appearing to be favorites who don’t do their job while others who work hard are not acknowledged.

6. Areas (such as the registries) appear to be glorified and praised leaving those in the other departments to feel like they are chopped liver.
reviews.review_advice:
1. 	Figure out how to marry the value that long-term employees bring to the table with their historical knowledge, skills, and connections with the newer ideas that newer employees have. Until all of the long-term employees are forced out or YOU figure this out, there will be discord and uneasiness.

2.	Don’t blatantly favor the money-making departments. Others work just as hard but may not have a position that will make the AAOS money.

3.	Communicate company-wide. Perhaps an email every other week or some other mass form of communication that isn’t dependent on each level below you to disseminate the information or upcoming changes. No milk and cookie-breaks or after-work parties – many are simply trying to get their work done or try to have a life outside of AAOS.

reviews.review_pros: I read the negative reviews on here and feel like I work at a different company.   I really like coming to work.  Is that not okay to say?  I really enjoy my work and I work with really smart, nice people. We are all encouraged to speak up and share our ideas.  There’s a lot of flexibility here.  The place is pretty quiet at 5pm.  The benefits are excellent.  They pay for tuition and classes.  They do a lot of things to make it fun and it seems like they’re always trying to improve.
reviews.review_cons: I think the people who are so negative are stuck in the past.  I was here then, too – it wasn’t perfect.  Is it perfect now? No.  Is anywhere perfect?  Nope.  Is it a good place to work?  Yes.  Would I encourage my friends to work here? Absolutely. To the people writing such nasty reviews, do you generally like being miserable? It seems you want everyone else to be miserable, too. Please stop hiding behind your anonymous reviews and go and talk to your manager or their manager. And if you aren’t able to do this, maybe you can take that energy and use it to find somewhere you would be happier.

reviews.review_pros: If you have contact with members, they are nice.
reviews.review_cons: Toxic environment that radiates from the C level.  The bullying that persists is mind boggling.  The culture is essentially a “cover yourself at all costs”  and though they tout empowerment of staff, nothing supports that.   If you have an HR issue, don’t waste your time enlisting HR for help.  If you have a project requiring support from IT, don’t bother and definitely don’t tie any goals that require IT support.  If you follow Finance procedures, don’t be surprised if they change them mid stream, don’t communicate them and then blame you for not knowing.
reviews.review_advice: Do some self reflection.

reviews.review_pros: A great group of physicians that dedicate their time to help promote education, guidelines and science-based initiatives.
reviews.review_cons: Its a frat party at the top.  Major turnover and a lack of job security.  I am not sure what these guys did in their past lives in cardiology, but they clearly don't have a vision, nor the experience to grow the business.  It seems as if bad decisions are now the norm.
reviews.review_summary: Place is going down the tubes...
reviews.review_advice: Board, please cut the snake off at the head.  Bring in someone that truly understands science and the mission of AAOS.  Not a lawyer that double-talks his way through life and focuses on his ego.

reviews.review_pros: Within walking distance of a Starbucks
reviews.review_cons: Unless you're desperate for employment (starving and or facing eviction) do NOT seek or accept employment at AAOS. 18 months ago, new leadership promised transparency and communication. 2 series of layoffs later and neither has happened.  New management is either not interested or incapable of motivating or managing staff. Departments are more silo’d then ever and morale has hit rock bottom.  Not sure what the qualifications are of the new CEO and his “crack” team of sycophants but one thing is obvious, since their tenure the reputation and standing of the Academy as a strong organization among the non for profit associations has diminished and instead of maintaining the organizations competitive edge their decision to outsource as much as possible to a commercial publisher has damaged the quality of their products.

Advice to the board
Dump the insecure CEO and his posse of clowns before they do any further damage and hire someone who understands and respects the mission of AAOS.

reviews.review_pros: The doctors involved as volunteers are terrific--action oriented, committed and challenging to work with.  There is a move toward basing treatment decisions on good data and the AAOS has a role in collecting that data.
reviews.review_cons: No one seems sure of their job--whether they will be there tomorrow or next week. Over the years, the things that have made the AAOS so great, including publishing important books and videos to excellent CME courses have been handed over to a commercial publisher and to orthopaedic specialty societies respectively. The AAOS is going into a new phase but I'm not sure it's a good one. Top leadership brought in a new team, which is its right, but the way many employees were axed does not speak well for the leadership.
reviews.review_summary: A shadow of its former self

reviews.review_pros: New leadership is from the "outside" bringing new and innovative ideas to the organization.  The organization is trying to get out of the non-profit stagnant culture and redefine themselves as an innovative professional organization leveraging new technologies to advance orthopaedics and improve overall patient care and safety.
reviews.review_cons: Can be challenging trying to introduce change in an organization that is used to doing things the same old way.  Newer staff must be willing become part of the change effort and help lead the value-driven efforts currently underway.
reviews.review_summary: Transformational change is a good thing
reviews.review_advice: Keep up the good fight to bring more value and sustainability to the organization and healthcare profession.

reviews.review_pros: Great co-workers and wonderful work environment
reviews.review_cons: Many changes happened without any notice from upper management
reviews.review_advice: Communication is key to any successful relationship and that needs to be considered

reviews.review_pros: The people are incredibly friendly, depending on your senior manager you can work from home, amazing office space, and ability to be promoted
reviews.review_cons: pay is okay, work can get repetitive.

reviews.review_pros: Great Benefits, challenging work with highly trained, appreciative medical professionals and many professional development opportunities.  Wonderful office location near public transportation and new office space.
reviews.review_cons:
Senior Management seemed to encourage work life balance, but in reality unreasonable deadlines and heavy work  mandates made this a pipe dream.  The annual cycle of activities would exponentially grow to include unnecessary meetings, internal training, and meaningless hr activities, including time consuming surveys on job satisfaction where the results were never circulated.  

Senior management consistently insisted on doing "as I say, not as I do".  Very demoralizing.
reviews.review_advice: Recommend a work environment that places a greater emphasis on staff value and respect.

reviews.review_pros: I won't say just exactly how long I have been here because if I do - there goes my anonymity; suffice it to say, it's been a long time, and I am proud of it.  I have been through several positions at the Academy, culminating in the job I currently have that I love with a passion.  I understand not everyone has been as fortunate, for a variety of objective and subjective reasons, but if you work hard and if you own your work, not afraid to stand accountable for the results - you will have a rewarding career at the Academy.  No, it is not a "mom and pop" operation it was years ago.  The Academy has been professionalized, the demands have increased, it has become more corporate in nature and environment, but it provides unmatched opportunities for creativity and personal growth.  Just don't expect to be coddled.  We are paid fairly, receive outstanding benefits, and support remarkable members.  There is much to be happy about and proud of.
reviews.review_cons: I have nothing negative to share.
reviews.review_summary: Those with negative reviews of the Academy need to grow up
reviews.review_advice: Keep doing what you're doing to make us more competitive and sustainable.

reviews.review_pros: Amazing employee benefits. Really can’t be beat for healthcare.  My unit had great flexibility in work from home and setting work hours.
reviews.review_cons: The new CEO was the beginning of going downhill. At first I was excited because I think a lot of us knew we needed a new direction and we needed to catch up with the times. However that positivity quickly turned negative. AAOS is losing lots of good people because of management. Lots of people let go, which yes, I understand restructuring is a natural part of new leadership.  There are people there in positrons with quite a bit of say who should NOT be there. And despite any complaints or issues brought up, those people remain there while the good ones leave.
reviews.review_summary: Not what it used to be
reviews.review_advice: Restore trust from your employees and follow through with “promises”. Hold people accountable for their work and actions.

reviews.review_pros: New leadership is from the "outside" bringing new and innovative ideas to the organization.  The organization is trying to get out of the non-profit stagnant culture and redefine themselves as an innovative professional organization leveraging new technologies to advance orthopaedics and improve overall patient care and safety.
reviews.review_cons: Can be challenging trying to introduce change in an organization that is used to doing things the same old way.  Newer staff must be willing become part of the change effort and help lead the value-driven efforts currently underway.
reviews.review_summary: Transformational change is a good thing
reviews.review_advice: Keep up the good fight to bring more value and sustainability to the organization and healthcare profession.

reviews.review_pros: It was a decent place to work. I thought the salary was fair and the benefits were reasonable. The work environment is pleasant, and I got to know many of the employees well.
reviews.review_cons: I honestly felt abused by my manager who treated me in a condescending and often offensive manner, in spite of the fact that her direct manager and the director of HR was fully aware of the way she treated me. It is not fun to go to a job where you feel you have no value--either as an employee or a human being. I would only recommend this place to a friend who was in dire need of a job.
reviews.review_summary: Hard to work at a place where you feel bullied every day
reviews.review_advice: Think you need to re-evaluate your revolving door. This used to be a fun, safe place to work. Now it has a reputation as a revolving door. Way too many people are fired, and what management doesn't understand or care about is that those firings reflect badly on management.

reviews.review_pros:
Benefit package is quite strong: good PPO plan, lots of time off with few restrictions on using it (in most departments anyways), generous employer retirement contribution, most employees are able to work remotely 1-2 days a week, etc. 

New leadership is making obvious efforts to shake up a complacent organization. We have moved from running at a million dollar plus annual operating loss to generating a small surplus of reserves. This necessitated restructuring and outsourcing of certain teams & roles that was painful. It's never easy to see people let go. 

The organization is moving towards transparency, there is still a ways to go. We receive consistent messaging at our All-Staff meetings around the priorities that we're working on: culture, strategy, and governance. Our CEO offers an open floor for questions from any employee at each all-staff meeting. The new strategic plan attempts to connect the work of each department to the overall strategic goals of the Academy. Lunch & Learns offer interested departments/teams the chance to spotlight their work (it'd be nice if lunch were at least sometimes provided for these).
reviews.review_cons:
The changes and strategic plan are not being embraced throughout the organization. There are a lot of long-tenured staff with deep institutional knowledge and there often seems to be tension between "old" and "new" employees. The perception of the "old" employees seem to be that that the "new" employees are arrogant and dismissive of the Academy's history and prior accomplishments and the perception of the "new" employees seems to be that the "old" employees are too stuck in their ways to ever change. We need to continue to work on a shared vocabulary and embrace a shared vision. There are a lot of meetings where people seem to just talk past each other and it's borderline impossible to get people pulling in the same direction that way. 

Salary ranges are reasonable, but often not top-of-the-market for Chicago (even for association work).
reviews.review_advice:
From the front-line level, it feels like the greatest disconnect may be at the director/senior manager level. The strategy and move towards transparency can only go so far as it is embraced and put into practice by the leaders in each department. They're the face of the organization to their team.

Continue the efforts to publicize what we're doing to make this an increasingly good place to work. Acknowledge where there have been missteps. People are reasonable and most won't expect you to be perfect, just human. Talk about how you're going to win hearts and minds and then follow through. People embrace authenticity and credibility.

reviews.review_pros: The doctors involved as volunteers are terrific--action oriented, committed and challenging to work with.  There is a move toward basing treatment decisions on good data and the AAOS has a role in collecting that data.
reviews.review_cons: No one seems sure of their job--whether they will be there tomorrow or next week. Over the years, the things that have made the AAOS so great, including publishing important books and videos to excellent CME courses have been handed over to a commercial publisher and to orthopaedic specialty societies respectively. The AAOS is going into a new phase but I'm not sure it's a good one. Top leadership brought in a new team, which is its right, but the way many employees were axed does not speak well for the leadership.
reviews.review_summary: A shadow of its former self

reviews.review_pros: Teamwork and communication are emphasized on all levels of management. The AAOS has good benefits--continuing education is supported financially. Professional development is encouraged through many different programs, including an in-house mentor program. The organization will pay for college course work up to $5,000 a year. Seminars and professional development courses are also covered 100%. Management encourages feedback in many ways including the annual performance reviews, workgroups on performance recognition, and the "green" initiatives.
reviews.review_cons: AAOS is a non-profit organization. Compensation can be low, but the benefits help compensate for the lack of pay.
reviews.review_summary: Room to grow at the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.
reviews.review_advice: Keep up the good work!

reviews.review_pros: The people that I worked with were great. I was lucky to be on a great team of employees who were able to work together and communicate well. Great place to get experience, especially if you are interested in the associations field and/or the health/medical field.
reviews.review_cons: The Academy has recently underwent some changes i.e. consolidating operations. The feeling around the organization at this time is rather uneasy.
reviews.review_summary: Great place to work, undergoing changes
reviews.review_advice: Don't be afraid to ask your subordinates for their thoughts or suggestions.

New management is either not interested or incapable of motivating or managing staff. Departments are more silo’d then ever and morale has hit rock bottom.  Not sure what the qualifications are of the new CEO and his “crack” team of sycophants but one thing is obvious, since their tenure the reputation and standing of the Academy as a strong organization among the non for profit associations has diminished and instead of maintaining the organizations competitive edge their decision to outsource as much as possible to a commercial publisher has damaged the quality of their products.

Advice to the board
Dump the insecure CEO and his posse of clowns before they do any further damage and hire someone who understands and respects the mission of AAOS.

reviews.review_pros: Great benefits and great training opportunities.
reviews.review_cons: The structural change that has come with new senior management has been borderline violent. The  environment that has been fostered is unhealthy, confusing and lacks a transparent direction. Change is to be assumed at any agency or association, however the ways in which change is currently being facilitated has created a culture of uncertainty and mistrust. It's unfortunate that such an important organization is unable to see the error of their ways. Massive lay offs with guaranteed future ones to come has resulted in the loss of some of the most stellar, creative and intelligent peers I have ever had the pleasure of collaborating with.
reviews.review_advice: Consider the direction you want to go and listen to those who have contributed so much. The loss of critical talent will only harm the association in the end.

reviews.review_cons: Flexible scheduling is present, but limited, expansion is needed to compete for talent in the Chicagoland market where work from home and casual environments are the norm.

reviews.review_pros: A great group of physicians that dedicate their time to help promote education, guidelines and science-based initiatives.
reviews.review_cons: Its a frat party at the top.  Major turnover and a lack of job security.  I am not sure what these guys did in their past lives in cardiology, but they clearly don't have a vision, nor the experience to grow the business.  It seems as if bad decisions are now the norm.
reviews.review_summary: Place is going down the tubes...
reviews.review_advice: Board, please cut the snake off at the head.  Bring in someone that truly understands science and the mission of AAOS.  Not a lawyer that double-talks his way through life and focuses on his ego.

reviews.review_pros: Great people to work with. Good learning experience.
reviews.review_cons: very corporate environment, creatives aren't very embraced. Lots of meetings
reviews.review_summary: Fast paced Great people, great work. Overall a good job
reviews.review_advice: Management style needs to be more supportive and knowledgeable of project timelines.

reviews.review_pros: Flexible schedule and great benefits
reviews.review_cons: "Hostile work environment" is an understatement--multiple reorganizations and layoffs within the last year have many employees wondering who will be next on the chopping block. Upper management scolds employees for listening to/spreading "negative" gossip, but the lack of transparency leaves employees with no alternative--ignore the grapevine & you risk being in the dark. Trust between staff & management is nonexistent. Telling staff that they can help build organizational culture is a tone-deaf reaction to the staff's rampant anxiety, which is a normal reaction to the layoffs.
reviews.review_advice: Some of you claim to have feelings: prove it. Start treating employees with respect.

reviews.review_pros: Good benefits, although some have been chiseled away. Traditionally decent salaries for longer term employees, although money is tight these days if you're not director level or higher. Management encourages staff engagement by asking them to post positive reviews on Glass Door. Bicycle building for charity at the staff picnic. Strong advancement opportunities for attractive young women and men with a brofessional attitude.
reviews.review_cons:
Reading through the reviews, you’ll see an interesting dichotomy. A bunch of negs written by “old” staffers who are unhappy with the direction of the company, and a bunch of pros written by “new” staffers telling people to suck it up and deal.

Personally, I’m not going to debate the wisdom of firing more than 10 percent of the workers without a coherent plan to distribute their responsibilities. I don’t want to argue about the cadre of excellent people who gave a shitt but ended up marginalized after multiple wacky reorgs. I didn’t come here to discuss the strategic shortcomings of a management team that claims to have improved transparency while barring staff from board meetings and distributing all bad news through subordinates.

And far be it from me to suggest that a membership organization has a responsibility to address the needs of its members. That’s nonsense. No one believes that. It's 2018, not 2008.

I left and I’m happy, thank you. My friends who remain in the Rosemont building are frustrated and depressed, but the smartest of them will land on their feet elsewhere. Quite a few already have. I have no ax to grind.

Except one…

The sexual harassment has got to stop. Now. I’m looking at you, upper management. It’s never acceptable, whether it takes place in a hallway or in an elevator or behind closed doors. It’s immensely stupid if it’s one of the first two, but perhaps that’s part of the transparency initiative. I don’t know. I do know that HR has been contacted on more than one occasion, but so far they seem to refuse to move on it. I have to wonder what their endgame is, because if the company gets sued, someone is probably going to ask why important people knew about it but never responded. One must admire the loyalty of the HR team, if not their decision making skills.

Work at the AAOS if you must. The benefits are decent and they pay the salaries on time. It’s better than cleaning septic tanks. But if you get hired, go into the situation with clear eyes. And if you’re a sexy young female, remember to bat them at the right people.
reviews.review_advice: Take a long hard look in the mirror.

review_employer_responses.response_text:
I have not yet responded to any posts here because I know perception is reality and disproving a negative is impossible. That said, I am responding to this post because the  assertions are not supported by facts, are insulting to all Academy staff and reflect a particularly toxic, reckless brand of feedback.   

I am very aware that the level of necessary change and transformation implemented since I joined the Academy has been significant and unprecedented. I am equally aware that these actions have upset the status quo, including reorganizations which resulted in layoffs and outsourcing. These changes have been unwelcome for some and celebrated by others. 

Every action taken was implemented after careful thought, for specific reasons and to make the Academy sustainable and successful into the future. As the CEO, it is one of my responsibilities to  ensure that we operate in a way that provides optimal member value. 

Simultaneously, we have dedicated a lot of focus to reassessing our strategic plan, applying discipline and metrics to execute on the current strategy, building a performance-based culture and undergoing a Board-led governance review. Many are finding an abundance of opportunities for growth, innovation and improvement. My hope is that those unhappy with the changes would be professional and decide either to contribute positively to the changes or move on rather than stay.

Turning to specific untruths made in the post, several employees have voiced strong disagreement with the negative reviews posted here. I have no concerns if someone suggested that those employees feel free to post their own experiences. But no one, at anyone's request, is soliciting positive reviews. 

During my fourteen-month tenure, I have been encouraged by the staff who have stepped-up to the challenges and, in a number of cases, earned well-deserved and often overdue promotions. It represents a win all around - for these employees and  the Academy. To say that those promotions were based on appearances or anything other than performance is insulting,  wrong, and mean spirited.

We look forward to continuing this trend and fully support the initiatives generated by the many talented AAOS employees. We are using new ways to encourage open and direct communication between staff  and AAOS leaders, including breakfasts with me and using other platforms to ask any question or provide feedback. As always, I welcome candid discussions.  I encourage staff to stop by and have a conversation with me - many do. You may not always agree with me, but we can have a respectful conversation.

The post also contains assertions about the environment and sexual harassment at the Academy.  I take these very seriously. The descriptions in the post are entirely incorrect and unfounded. From day one, I have stressed that the Academy will be a workplace where everyone is treated with dignity and respect. Harassment of any type is unacceptable and not tolerated. These are not just words and aspirations. We have an entire framework of policies and procedures to ensure a respectful and productive environment.   Wherever and whenever any such issues come to our attention, they are addressed promptly, thoroughly and professionally. 

All staff are required to take regularly schedule anti-harassment training.  Our last training occurred in 2017; additional on-site training will be held in August. We have an ethics hotline which allows for anonymous reporting.  However, anyone who experiences or witnesses harassment or inappropriate behavior is strongly encouraged to report it to their manager or director, the Chief HR Officer or the General Counsel.  Every report  is thoroughly investigated until a final determination is made. One of HR’s roles in this process is to ensure freedom from any related retaliation for making a report. Retaliation will not be tolerated. The result of any investigation is a private matter between the Academy and the individuals directly involved. While we do not publicly share those outcomes, absolutely nothing is brushed under the carpet.  This is non-negotiable for me. 

Good luck in your new endeavors now that you have left the Academy. I think it was the right decision.

If you’re still reading, thanks for hanging in there with me.  For those thinking about working at the Academy, I  hope that you can weigh the difference between anonymous toxic assertions and making up your own mind based on due diligence and outreach. The Academy is an outstanding, mission-driven place to work. Our offices are filled with smart, talented, engaged and committed staff of all kinds. Everyone has an opportunity to make a positive impact.  We empower our employees to act, encourage innovation, support our staff in their professional growth and provide a pretty darn good and flexible work environment.   Thanks. TOM AREND

reviews.review_pros: A few good staff are left but not many.   The physician volunteers are great to work with.  The organization has an important mission.
reviews.review_cons: Major reorganization (laid off over 30 employees right before the holidays) by new leadership has led to stressful work environment and directors and managers manipulating situations to keep their jobs at the expense of their staff. Management is not interested in hearing ideas or suggestions - they want followers not leaders.
reviews.review_summary: A lot of turmoil and poor communication is leading to a dysfunctional culture.
reviews.review_advice: Start to talk to the front line staff and really listen to them instead of fielding an employee engagement survey that was only for show.

reviews.review_pros: If you have contact with members, they are nice.
reviews.review_cons: Toxic environment that radiates from the C level.  The bullying that persists is mind boggling.  The culture is essentially a “cover yourself at all costs”  and though they tout empowerment of staff, nothing supports that.   If you have an HR issue, don’t waste your time enlisting HR for help.  If you have a project requiring support from IT, don’t bother and definitely don’t tie any goals that require IT support.  If you follow Finance procedures, don’t be surprised if they change them mid stream, don’t communicate them and then blame you for not knowing.
reviews.review_advice: Do some self reflection.

reviews.review_pros: Good benefits. Good benefits. Nice building. Parking. Well-known brand. Huge Annual Meeting.
reviews.review_cons:
There are many cons to this organization, it's a mess! The atmosphere is so negative and everyone is scared for their jobs due to the lack of transparency. 

Poor compensation compared to other markets.

Meetings department is rough; people are overworked and all live in constant fear. There is no room for advancement with no hopes of change. 

Education and Publications department are in ruin due to the last Chief Education Officer. Hopefully, with the new replacement things will get better. However, it's hard to repair years of damage which means more layoffs are possibly on the horizon.

IT department is poorly structured and lack talent in many areas.

Many individuals in leadership roles are either incompetent or lack experience with no idea how to manage or lead. It doesn't help that some leaders have very little to no personalities. Many have been here for years and have not current with the times.

Things were not in the greatest shape with the previous CEO but when the new Sheriff and Deputy came aboard, they created a toxic environment that is now in a worse state than it was before a mass lay-off (over 30-people in one day). 

Between those months before the layoff, the AAOS suffered poor morale and productivity in some departments because no one knew if their job was secure or not.  Till this day, the effects are still being felt. 

There's a huge lack of transparency, no matter how much senior, executive, and c-level management will try to say otherwise. Your job can be safe one day, but you won't know what the future holds because everything is kept secret. 

I really hope that this place improves with new leadership, but I doubt it will. There are still some good people here, but everyone is looking elsewhere for a more stable working environment.

I would wait years before ever considering a job at this place, with the hopes of new changes and leadership being in place.
reviews.review_advice: Stop trying to imitate what other medical organizations are doing in terms of business and structure.

reviews.review_pros: The people. Colleagues are great- at least in membership. I’ve heard there your usual office politics around certain people and things but to be expected anywhere and it wasn’t something I really ever interacted with. I felt like upper management and my VP listened to my ideas and feedback on various projects, and some of them were even implemented. They do benchmarking within the non profit sector and corporate level, so I feel like salary is fair. SF isn’t made for nonprofit workers not established with their own home pre 2005 though, so that can be tough. Also, Dr. Parks is super approachable, even in passing in the hallways. He works hard to not give off the “doctor” vibe with the staff while still remaining trustworthy.
reviews.review_cons: Members can be a pain in the butt, but to be expected in a medical professional association field. SF economics/culture makes it hard to survive financially. Also- I wish IT pretended to care slightly more.

reviews.review_pros:
Great place for a new graduate or older person looking for stability / health insurance. Some employees have been here for 10-30+ years, so it’s probably not going anywhere. Facilities Dept. is amazing, from dealing with small office issues to organizing fun events like Opening Day Hot Dog parties, Halloween parties, Ping Pong Tournaments, etc. On the whole, really nice, friendly, quirky people. Some of the people in higher positions are mean, but are easily avoidable if you’re a layperson. 

In my case, good work/life balance, but I know some staff who work well into the early morning and weekends. It apparently depends on your position.

Shower room with towels. Amazing staff in mail room—if you’re addicted to Amazon Prime or online shopping in general, this is a safe place to get all your shopping delivered.

Casual attire.
reviews.review_cons:
Noticeable distinction between higher-ups, who make $100,000 to a million dollars a year, and the the little people, who make below market rate. I was appalled to learn my salary, which admittedly is below market rate, is what some people in the office make in their yearly bonus :(  And yet, there is constant complaining that the organization is losing money. How about some of the staff cut their 5-figure bonuses?

1-2% yearly “Merit Increases” for low-totem people is an insult.

Nice office, but located in Ghiradelli Square, which is difficult to get to if you don’t live in the immediate area. 

You are required to work for a week at their annual meeting, which takes place in different cities. This requires lots of schmoozing, standing, walking, and wearing very ugly purple uniforms. You are fed cafeteria food, and sometimes it's not too bad. You will also be rewarded with a decent meal at a restaurant. It makes sense they would make the peons work at these meetings though, so that they can save money that needs to go towards the salaries and bonuses of the Directors, VPS, etc.

This is an old-fashioned place. If you still have a little life left in you, you might start to feel stifled here.
reviews.review_summary: Not bad if you're really young or an older person or in a high position
reviews.review_advice: You guys in the money-making high positions are lucky!

reviews.review_summary: A Good Association Compared to Others in the Physician Community

reviews.review_pros:
The mission of the American Academy of Ophthalmology is to protect sight and empower lives by serving as an advocate for patients and the public, leading ophthalmic education, and advancing the profession of ophthalmology

Key Points: 
It's a 120-year old organization with around 32,000 ophthalmologist members, and it recently launched a new branding initiative to take it to the 21st century (a good thing, as it has been received well by the membership and others).

Great opportunity to work with over 900 amazing, dedicated, and kind volunteer physicians (ophthalmologists) supported by nearly 200 similarly dedicated, collaborative, and helpful staff.
 
Collegiality and mutual respect for coworkers is the norm.

Holds one of the largest medical specialty meetings in the world that only a handful of cities can handle; it is simply amazing to see (no pun intended) the organization work together to make it a success. 

Recently received Accreditation with Commendation (the highest award) from the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (nice collaboration with the Education and Meetings Divisions).  

The Academy's launch of the IRIS Data Registry is a game changer, as it's the largest clinical eye disease registry which will play a critical role in improving the delivery of quality eye care for the future (I believe it might be the largest medical registry in the world as of today). 

Internal: 

Great 401(k) plan with a 10% match (if you give 3%), but if you give nothing (0%), you still get 7%. 

New hires start earning 2 weeks/year of vacation, 3 weeks/year at three years, 4 weeks/year at six years, and 5 weeks/year at 15 years plus a personal day and typical holidays. Also, time off is usually granted from Christmas through New Year’s, another nice perk.

Recognition initiatives have been rolled out including Bonusly and spot bonuses.

Staff (reduced rate) parking is reasonable (compared to other employers in the city)

New automated, secured bike cage and free bike rentals to get errands done in the city

Weekly free fresh fruit delivery is made to the break rooms. Newly installed water bottle filling stations have been installed. 

A large Starbucks is on the first floor (one of the larger ones in California).  Cappuccino coffee machines are on each floor (if you don't want to pay for a Starbucks).

Even free snacks for all can be found if you know where to find them (2nd floor: IT, 3rd floor: Education, and 4th floor: Meetings)

If you want more of a selection, the Academy installed an Avanti mini-market to allow the purchase of food and beverages at a reduced rate in the remodeled break room and a nice ping-pong table has appeared (even a catered annual table tennis tournament has started). Even all of the floor kitchens have been remodeled.

Great location allows for a nice run, jog, or stroll to Aquatic Park with nice views of the Golden Gate and Alcatraz and a new multi-purpose workout room for Pilates and yoga with writable walls was installed. After a good workout, there are multiple private showers with shampoo, soap, and free towel service.
reviews.review_cons:
It doesn't have free daily lunches or dinners like Google or other technology companies: it's a non-profit that's been fiscally responsible to its Board with its members' dues. Even with the financial downturn in 2008-2009, it didn't have layoffs unlike other companies (public, private, or non-profit). Unlike a publicly traded company scrambling to make the quarterly numbers or a startup dealing with venture capitalists who can sell it out in a few years for a profit, the Academy has provided solid stability over its 120-year history (several friends have stated they were pleased to focus on the mission and give up the stress being bought out or the possibility of layoffs). 

Comments about "horrible" managers and non-performers may be true to certain extent (All places have them. Let’s be real), but the environment is starting to change for the better where a number of these individuals have retired, been coached appropriately, or have left (finally).  A new leadership development initiative for a select group of managers was launched and recent leadership participants (alumni) have met to improve collaboration, understand leadership challenges, and break silos. A culture of respect for others is a strong part of the Academy environment: people who are passive-aggressive, loud-mouthed, incompetent, and/or lazy won't last long. 

The Academy is not a large organization, so promotions may not be as fast, but recently a minor reorganization and a new mindset have allowed for internal and cross-divisional promotions at various levels ranging from individual contributors, middle management, and even executive management (AMS, Brand and Creative, Education, IT, Meetings, and Quality & Data Science come to mind).  

Long hours can be an issue especially with employees who work in core mission areas, but management and HR allow for flexibility as needed.

Though the location may be great when you get there, the commute can be a challenge for those who come across the Bay Bridge, though there are options to flex your work schedule.

Agree with others that the dental plan could be better.
reviews.review_summary: A Great Place with a Great Mission
reviews.review_advice: Thanks for making the effort to change for the better. Continue to thank your people who make it happen, be fair, be transparent, and don't be afraid to admit if it doesn't work the first time (you'll be respected if you do).

reviews.review_pros:
Meaningful work - protecting sight and empowering lives, you have the opportunity to make a positive impact every day
Strong community and culture - lots of smart, hard-working people who are good at what they do and want to make a difference. We also work with amazing volunteer physicians
Beautiful location - Billion dollar views and great trails right outside the door and a nice office
Great benefits - 401(k) program is awesome, vacation time is generous, additional perks like yoga and Pilates classes on site and the office is closed between Christmas and New Year's Day. Overall, they take good care of us
Open to new ideas and innovations - we're leading some really exciting technologies that will lead to breakthroughs in health care, and new ideas and innovations are encouraged from all levels
Stability - we've been around a long time and have solid plans for healthy long-term growth. Many of our team have been here for decades
Flexibility - depending on your position, there may be opportunities for a somewhat flexible schedule or working from home from time to time
Professional development - on-site professional development opportunities classes are provided, and off-site professional development activities are supported
reviews.review_cons:
Promotion - because we are so stable and people stay here for a long time, there can be limited opportunities for upward mobility
Commute - due to the location of the office, the commute can be a bit tricky
Raises - we get an annual pay increase, but it's modest - more like a cost of living adjustment
Staffing - we tend to be understaffed in many departments

reviews.review_advice: Figure out a way to make your middle-managers accountable for the way they go about managing people. In short: man up and face these issues.

reviews.review_pros: Work at the Academy supports a cause you can feel good about -- helping the doctors who help people preserve their vision. You also work under a pretty diverse executive team (which is to say, it's more representative than other organizations I've seen). One of the better-run associations in medicine, it's a leader in the industry whose shrewd management brought it through the circa-2008 downturn without layoffs. Some of the benefits are nice -- they get a biweekly fruit delivery, have a free bike program to help employees run errands and offer generous vacation to longstanding employees. They also have an unofficial but decade-long practice of giving staff the stretch between Christmas Eve and New Year's off as paid leave and recently introduced an annual bring-your-dog-to-work day. Though the commute can be challenging, some managers allow occasional telework, and the operations staff worked with Chariot to provide an alternative to MUNI. Recent efforts have also sought to get more employee input on the company in general.
reviews.review_cons: Limited room for advancement and terrible compensation policies if you do advance. If you get promoted one job grade, your pay raise is capped at 5 percent, no negotiation available. They supposedly benchmark salaries against industry every three years, but I had such an evaluation shortly after a promotion and they somehow concluded my new pay matched industry standards. It did NOT, according to my research on Salary.com, but when I asked for the data that supported their conclusion, they never responded. The Academy was a great place to work seven-plus years ago, but work-life balance can be pretty bad in some departments, with little to no recognition for sacrifice. After one huge, extremely demanding project I worked on, the core team got only the usual annual bonus for that year (less than one paycheck after taxes; bonuses depend on the fiscal-year outcome) and a worse-than-usual thank-you meal. After putting in about 130 hours' overtime toward the end of the project -- the most in my near-decade there, with multiple 12-hour days -- I got only two days of unofficial comp time and a fractionally higher annual merit increase. (I don't think our team had any larger a merit pool, despite the project; I think that was just how my manager chose to allocate it.) Probably related to these factors, 2015 brought unusually high turnover.
reviews.review_summary: Industry-leading non-profit with unusually high recent turnover
reviews.review_advice: Change the promotion-raise policy. A former HR employee I spoke to told me 10 percent raises seemed more fair. You clearly expect more than 5 percent more of someone who gets promoted. Why put them in a position of making a lower effective hourly rate? Also consider a better comp-time policy. People who have to work weekends or holidays should get a day-for-day substitution. I know of people who travel almost every weekend in January and hardly seem to get any time off that month. How can they possibly do their best work with no break? It would also be great if you offered a more meaningful bonus to people who make significant sacrifices for certain projects. I've heard executives talk about how the Academy rewards hard work, but that's not true. You don't -- and that's probably a big part of the recent high turnover. It's certainly destroyed most of my loyalty.

reviews.review_advice:
-Positive feedback = boosts morale, which in turn makes people want to work harder
-Stop pinching pennies, and implement professional development (Learnit doesn't count)
-All Exec's should have an understanding of everyone's job and know how to use basic functions in Word, Excel, etc.
-Everyone should be paid at least the average for their field

reviews.review_pros: Great 401k, smart people, friendly atmosphere, wonderful mission. Opportunities to learn, grow and explore if you have a good boss.
reviews.review_cons: Horrible location (Fisherman's Wharf). Not much room for advancement, as many upper management have been there 10, 20, even 30 years. Work/life balance depends on the department you're in.
reviews.review_advice: Allow opportunities for learning and growth in our current jobs AND beyond. Keep working on the feedback from our engagement survey.

reviews.review_pros: Members and staff were good to work with. Decent salary, benefits and flexibility.
reviews.review_cons: Not much room for advancement.

reviews.review_pros: I worked in IT for this company for many years, and while they have a few things to work on, it's generally a very great place to work!  Very down-to-earth people, within IT and out.  Not a great amount of vacation time to start off, but some other decent perks.  Great benefits and stability.  Salary seemed fairly competitive, but not anything to write home about.
reviews.review_cons: Their technology is lagging behind a bit, and there's not a lot of room to play catch-up with the pace they progress.  There's room for innovation, and they welcome positive change and growth, but the company needs to value IT higher than it did when I worked there.
reviews.review_summary: What you need to know about working at AAO

reviews.review_pros: fun work environment, Most of the staff are easy to work with.
reviews.review_cons: benefits not as good as it used to be.

reviews.review_pros: Flexible and generous time-off, travel to the Annual Meeting, pleasant building/work environment, intelligent senior management, great Members, and a few colleagues that make a big difference.
reviews.review_cons:
There is zero opportunity for substantial career growth. People who do grow their career here do so by staying for 7-10 years in one position (and no, there is no extra challenge within these positions) and therefore are not the innovative and motivated type of people who a company should seek to fill those positions. "Lifers" are real here, and not in a good way. Dental insurance is definitely not comparable to the norm. Pay isn't great, and the "raises" are laughable. Also, there is huge inequity in the unofficial perks (ie. working from home, leaving early, professional education, etc.) 

While there are a few really impressive people in the mix, they are rare - if you are intelligent, you are likely to outgrow them quickly. You'll quickly feel the "if you're the smartest person in the room, you're in the wrong room." If you're bright and motivated, this is not the place for you.
reviews.review_summary: Not the place for bright, motivated individuals
reviews.review_advice:
Cut down staff and restructure departments to make roles more efficient and challenging - and save $$$.
Create better opportunities for young/bright talent; these are the people you NEED to create an innovative environment. 
Switch dental insurance from Guardian. 
IT and Management should not be allowed to "work from home" - because most of them aren't.

reviews.review_pros: Recognition from direct report and 100% of the credit for achievements. Pay is competitive, 401 k, paid vacation and sick time and we close at the end of the year (a gift of time)
reviews.review_cons: Executive management does not see or recognize the same achievements. Standards are different from division to division, not a great deal of upward and forward movement, people stay in their positions for extended periods of time.
reviews.review_advice: Recognize the staff that word hard at being the best at what they do. The people that provide an added service and are not just watching the clock.

reviews.review_pros: Innovative, forward thinking medical society.  Lots of new, exciting things coming out of the Academy.

reviews.review_summary: Great for a medical society... but plenty of more exciting options in the Bay Area
reviews.review_advice: Hire younger, design-forward employees.

reviews.review_cons: Extremely limited promotion opportunities, as many in upper management do not move, which also equates to limited financial growth.
reviews.review_advice: Stop micromanaging, creates an unproductive work environment.  Trust people to do their jobs.

company_name: American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons

reviews.review_pros: My father worked at his company for over 25 years and until I came to work at AAOMS, I could not possibly see why anyone would want to work at the same place for so long. It really is all about the people and the culture created that helps foster this sense of belonging. It is rare and I am lucky and thankful to be part of such a merry crew.
reviews.review_cons: The nature of associations makes larger changes slower to execute than in a private company because decisions are made with great care and weighed in committees. While this can take some getting used to, especially coming from a start-up environment, ultimately it proves very effective because all outcomes are considered which usually leads to the best path forward.
reviews.review_summary: An old-school association that values its staff and cares about their well-being and success
reviews.review_advice: Embracing technology to solve operational and logistical problems has been very well done thus far, especially in light of the challenges presented by the pandemic. Keep it up!

reviews.review_pros: This company offer 401k with 3 percent match after 90 days of employment, they will provide lots of training. you will get 6 holidays but that is it
reviews.review_cons: No vacation time for the first year- after year one you will get 1 week, 5 years until 3 weeks.  No raise at all, no overtime, no room for advancement, health insurance will cost you more than your paycheck for one week. If you do not produce within the first month they will let you go. They are kind of old school when it comes to management style they want you at your desk and working all the time and they will micromanage you all the time. They will tell you that you will be working 40 hours a week with 1 hour for lunch 8am to 5pm but once you start they want you to work more hours. Forget about breaks.
reviews.review_summary: Company that could be the best!
reviews.review_advice: Get with the times on vacation at least 3 weeks off, give raises every year and better compensation, not the $35,000 that you offer, stop making your people work 40 or more hours without overtime. It is against the law. Make sure your people get drug screened especially management
